content: Are you happy? I hope you’re happy. I’m happy.
At least I think I am. You’re here. That helps!
But you have to go away again. It happens. I don’t blame you.
It sure is nice at Winslow High School for you. Being a Ward, having friends. People to support you, care for you. Ever since you transferred from Chicago! You wanted this. You really did.
We both know why you’re here.
And that’s okay! I understand.
You have friends. Everybody loves having friends. Maybe even romantic interests. In high school, anything is possible.
Good luck! I hope you have fun.
I really do. I want you to have fun.
%%choice_load%%
Ah, Winslow High. You stare at it for a moment, breathing in that sweet, brisk autumn air with a grin; taking it all in is important. Maybe you’ll do it again.
Then someone’s hand shoves you forward, and Sophia Hess passes you, giving a rough nod of acknowledgment.

“S-sup,” you manage, the wind knocked out of you, then decide to fix it. Especially after she rolls her eyes and smirks at you. That condescending bullshit. Time flip-flops for a brief moment, and you’re back in the moment, the scent of someone’s sugary aromatic beverage pretending to be coffee in your lungs, crackly-dry leaves swept to the side, and the cold, bracing air; it’s all right there, and you love every second of it.
You spin to the left, dodging her push. Easy. “‘Sup,” you say.
She blinks, then shakes her head. “Go to hell. How many tries did that take you?”
“None. Heard you from a mile away.”
“You’re so full of shit,” she says, shoving you again. You let it happen, this time. “What did Piggot say?”

“That my performance has been exemplary and that I should keep up the good work.” The lie slips out easily, smooth and obvious. It’s always been fun shooting the shit with Sophia. Or at the very least, giving her shit. “She’s got it out for me. That’s all. And has my best interests in mind.”

“Told you so,” Sophia says, a delighted smirk on her face. You let her have it, shrugging as you open your locker. “She’s just looking for an excuse to remove you from active duty. Make you less useful. It’s an easy out for her. Wait for something to go wrong, take you off-duty, suspend you, whatever she wants. Fattie doesn’t have power, so she just barks like a fucking chihuahua.”

“Well, I’m perfect. So whatever. Doesn’t even matter.” Your books are scooped neatly into your bag, and you glance off to your left after catching a flash of red hair in the crowd. Waving isn’t strictly necessary, but you do it anyway. “Ems,” you say, giving her a nod as she opens her locker two down from you.
She glances askance at you before returning the nod and turning back to her locker.
Between Sophia Hess, Madison Clements, and Emma Barnes, you’re safe. A popularity windbreak in the caustic bitchfest that Winslow tends to be.
However, it’s even better than that. Because as you look around, you see her. Taylor. The girl you’re
%%choice_mc%%
She’s wearing a lumpy sweater and jeans, her eyes glancing around behind her glasses. Looking for you. And for them.
She’s right to, after all, they haven’t stepped down their efforts.
“Taylor,” you say, smiling. A thin, wan smile. It’s easy enough for you to pretend. “Good to see you.”
She glances for the others. They’ve made themselves scarce for now. Good. Rewinding to avoid Taylor noticing is such a pain. “Hey,” she says, a murmur with a tinge of hope.
“Good morning,” you try next, “are you alright?”

“Yeah,” she says, opening her locker. There’s not much in there. 48, 22, 65, as you can name off the top of your head. It’s not like it’s been hard to memorize her combination. A few seconds rewound, one number. Then another. Then the last. “Fine.”
You shrug, leaning against the locker next to hers. “Sure.”

She seems annoyed as she closes her locker, looking at her bag, then shaking her head and starting to head toward class. However, she's not upset at you. Her disposition indicates it was probably something missing from her locker again. It was probably Madison, this time. You haven't seen her yet today, after all.
“Hey,” you say, “if there’s anything I can do...”

You know she hears you, but she doesn’t respond. Other than a slight sagging of her shoulders as she moves away. That’s fine. An IV drip of friendship works. Pretending to also be bullied, to be victimized, but bravely being her friend, that also works. Practically speaking, it’s easy to push her buttons.
Who to eat with for lunch, though? The others will probably be busy, but you’ve been thinking about—
%%choice_lunch%%
%%choice_save%%

You don’t share all of Sophia’s philosophical views. You do derive pleasure from pushing people around. Manipulating them. Watching them make mistakes. It’s something you don’t have to deal with. The only mistakes you make are the ones you let people see.

It makes you wonder how much goes into that front of strength Sophia puts up, how much practice went into perfecting it. And how much effort goes into what Emma does. She’s the one that pushes Taylor down, after all. Sophia eggs her on.

And you do too, in your own way. You get your food and sit down in front of Emma. There’s no danger of Taylor finding out. It’s not as if anyone talks to her. And it’s not as if she’d dare to come in. Maybe Madison is at the bathroom stall where Taylor hides, pouring sugar and salt, water, soda, whatever is on hand. All while Sophia stands in front of the door, keeping it closed with a firm hand.

The perspective is an intriguing one. Madison tends to do the petty things, elements that hurt material possessions. Sophia is physically abusive, whether it’s verbal or small acts of violence. You wonder how she learned these. Maybe you’ll ask later, then rewind, ferreting it out.
Emma’s acts are more emotional, using what she knows about Taylor to strike. It’s a creative means of excising their former relationship. Bringing it out in the open, hitting Taylor hard as possible.
Emma smiles at you.
You smile back.

The noise of people talking in the background makes for a good distraction. You can listen to stray pieces of conversation. You blink as you realize that Emma is speaking. You focus on her neck, her face, her eyes, her lips. It’s a bit of a jealous twinge as you listen to her. How long did she spend on it? The foundation is flawlessly blended with her skin. You can’t see where it ends on her neck. You know she can’t sleep sometimes. But there’s no bags there. Her eyeliner is teeth-grinding in its perfection.
When you do it, you take pride in repeating it, reversing time so that there are no mistakes. But hers looks professionally done. It probably was, you reason. “Yes,” you say, “I agree.”

“I know. Can you believe her? She comes to school dressed like that,” Emma says, rolling her eyes, “I saw her when I was going to my modeling thing. You know. Just walking down the street, same outfit.”
“Yes,” you say, taking a critical eye to Emma’s hair, “probably homeless.”
“I guess it’s good that you don’t sit next to her. She smells like a dumpster,” Emma continues, “probably doesn’t have any other clothes. Poor thing.”

You scoop a fork of food into your mouth, barely tasting it. You chew. Emma’s hair looks like it’s out of a shampoo commercial. She’s done some extensions recently. They blend in, making it look fiery. If you tried to do that, it would just look tacky.
More food goes into your mouth, is chewed, then swallowed.

“Ugh,” Emma glances to the side. You follow her eyes. It’s the girl. Is it because she looks similar to Taylor? Did she say the wrong words to Emma, causing your friend to take offense? Emma smirks, then rolls her eyes, turning her attention back to you. “So,” she says, “tell me about what’s happening after school.”

You toy with the piece of orange jello, pressing the fork against it. It bleeds through in five slices. “Probably patrols, or console duty. We’ll see. That one is up to the boss. Maybe nothing will happen.”
“You don’t really think that,” Emma says, that same smirk on her face.
You smile, then shake your head slightly. “We’ll let you know.”

“Fight those dragons,” she says, flippant. Done poking at her food, she picks it up. “I can’t stand this anymore. You want any of this?” She doesn’t really mean it. She’s looking at it with a sneer. It makes her face look a lot worse.
“Nah. It’s disgusting,” you say.
“You’re eating it,” she points out.
“Keeping my strength up. Gotta fight those dragons,” you say.
She laughs. She has a nice laugh. All false kindness and joy.  Then she leaves, and you’re left there, eating the rest of the cafeteria food.
Once you’re done, you slide your tray into the receptacle and saunter off to

%%choice_save%%

choices: Find Taylor. You can probably find out what they did.
Just head to class. You can comfort her later.

content: You head to the bathroom. Not the one nearest to the cafeteria. The one a bit further away. You’re all but certain Taylor has been hiding there. That’s why you told the others. It’s an interesting moment, to guess what they’ve done. How upset Taylor will be. What her face will show, and what won’t. You admire that aspect of her, the ability to close it all in. To shove all that emotion away to deny you, and the others.

There’s the door. You grasp the handle and pull it open, taking in the sight. It’s hard not to break into laughter at the sight. You give into the urge, and Taylor’s shocked expression almost pushes you into forgetting your limit.
Time slithers back, and you open the door again, composing yourself.

Taylor is picking up her books, her pens and pencils, all scattered on the ground. She appears to be untouched, although her bag is in the sink, and the water is running. The funny part was her hair, hanging down, almost touching the ground. With her lanky stature, it makes her appear spindly, hair attached to arms and legs, all picking up objects, strewn across the ground.

You let the door shut behind you a bit louder than you opened it. She jumps, looking up at you. Her jaw is clenched, her eyes giving you an emotionless glare that softens upon seeing that it’s you. She pushes her hair out of her face, about to say something, then goes back to picking up the soiled objects. Her hands are trembling.

You crouch down nearby, helping. It occurs to you that you should have perhaps banged yourself up, disheveled your clothing, perhaps. It would have given more credence to your help, elicited empathy from her. You pick up one of the books. Required reading falls apart, a chapter or so pulling away in your hand. You let it fall, letting out a “damn it” of frustration.
Taylor lets out a choked sob of helpless laughter.

“I’ll pay for it,” you say, scooping up the book and tossing it into the trash. You wipe your hands off, taking your bag off and rummaging around for loose change and bills. You hold out a handful of paper. Your eyes count it as you wait for her to take it. Seven, maybe eight dollars. Not enough to hurt, and probably a little over what the book cost. “Is that enough?” you ask worriedly, your eyes widening, “I think I can-”
“No-you don’t need to,” she says, and you press the money into her free hand.
“It’s fine,” you say, forcing a forced smile. It works. Taylor flinches, looking guilty.
“I-” she starts, “you should get to class. I’ll finish up. I don’t want you to be late too.”
You hand her a somewhat less damp notebook, then sigh. “For what it’s worth,” you say, haltingly, “I’m sorry. You don’t deserve this.”
Taylor’s lips press together, all thin and white. Her eyes are damp. She looks down and away, hair concealing her face. “Thank you,” she finally says.

All things considered, their prank was reasonably creative. Ruin her stuff without a mark on her. Did they grab her bag before she’d gotten into the bathroom? Dumped it out, kept the door shut until they’d doused it? “No problem,” you say, standing and heading over to the sink. You rinse your hands off before heading toward the door.

As the door swings shut behind you, you hear a wet thud as something hits a wall. It was probably Madison that poured the drink, and Sophia who took the bag, you reason with a smile as you head toward class.
English. Come to think of it, you could have offered her your book instead of the money. Oh well.
You sit in English class, half-listening to the teacher. Occasionally, you’ll use your ability to catch something he said. Mostly, you’re considering what you’ll be doing after school.

It’s weird to think that you’ll be heading to the afterschool activity of the Wards, chasing criminal scum, etcetera. The heroes of tomorrow. And as prestigious and stuffy as it is, you could skip. Worst case scenario they send a car to pick you up and call your mom.
But you do enjoy interacting with the other Wards. Aegis is pretty attractive.

%%choice_save%%

choices: Head to the rig with Sophia
Skip Wards stuff, hang out with Emma

content: Taylor heads toward the bus stop. You can see the damp spot on the bottom of her bag. You’ll have to ask Sophia exactly what she did in the bathroom. Probably not in the car ride there, though. Or in the locker room, with pint-size terror listening in. Or on patrol, with whoever on console decides to listen in. Maybe before class tomorrow will do. You prefer not to deal with the texts they exchange, although you’ve peeked over shoulders often enough.
But you settle into the car with Sophia, who gives you a knowing smirk. She’s already taken some of her toolkit out of her bag, along with her homework.
“You’re actually doing your homework,” you say, incredulous.
“You got a problem with that?” says her mother, looking at you through the mirror.
You smile for the camera. “I have no problem with that. She’s just never done it in the car before.”
“Have free time,” Sophia mutters, “might as well.”

What a load of bullshit. You know for a fact Sophia will talk about her mother in the most furious of tones. It’s also probable that she won’t talk about it in front of Gallant or Vista. She hates those expressions of weakness. Is she afraid it’ll be used against her by them?
Following the procedure to get on the Rig, in the Wards elevator, you laugh.
She punches you in the arm. You rewind, then dodge.
“Did I get you?” she asks, glaring.
“Nope,” you say, smiling. “How much homework did you get done?”
“Fucking none. Shut the hell up,” she says, as the elevator opens. She tries to punch you again, and you actually manage to dodge this time.
She gives up. You smirk.
Sophia stalks into the hallway and surprises of surprises, she passes the iris scan. She heads in, tossing her backpack to the side.

Aegis is sitting on the couch, mask off, skinsuit on. He reaches for the remote, and the muscles on his back and his shoulderblades move in a most agreeable manner. “Hey,” he says, looking over at the two of you before he turns off the television. “Ready for patrol?”
“Like this?” you ask, a smile on your face as he stands, grabbing his mask from the coffee table. “I guess.”
“Whenever you’re ready,” he says pointedly to Sophia, “we can head out.”
“Oh good,” Sophia says, and although you’re not looking, you can feel her eyes rolling. “I’ll go get dressed.”
“You two lovebirds have fun,” you say, doing your best not to let annoyance creep into your voice.
“Am I on console, then?”
“Is that you volunteering?” Aegis says, a gentle rebuke in his voice.
Fuck.
“Sure,” you say, pasting a happy grin on your face. “I’ll stay on overwatch. Dispatch is all me, etcetera.”
“Sounds good. Thank you,” he says.

Getting dressed into your suit isn’t much of a pain. Grey with golden highlights make up much of your armored costume. You’re pretty satisfied with it, along with the domino mask, which is currently staring at you from the keyboard. “Hello, this is Console, how may I direct your call,” you say, but don’t turn the microphone on just yet. It’s annoying to watch and listen from the proverbial watchtower, all shit work, no action.

At least you’re getting some homework done as Aegis and Shadow Stalker go about their patrol. It’s annoying because you know exactly why Aegis goes with her. Not because of any attraction, but because he’s one of the few that can keep up with her when she decides that she needs to scare the shit out of some muggers.

And it annoys the hell out of you when she does it to you. Her mobility lets her get ahead of you, and to the action way before you can get there. At least Aegis has the courtesy not to engage unless it’s looking grim for whatever poor sap is getting it.
But whatever. There’s another reason why Aegis wanted you on Console. The whole time thing does come in handy for giving what is essentially a precognitive warning about shit going down.
Do you care enough to use it? It’s not like they’re in any serious danger.
%%choice_next%%
%%choice_save%%

choices: Warn them if danger shows up
Go make a snack. If they get pissy, whatever. Today is a slow day anyway.
If serious shit happens, then warn them. Otherwise, you have homework.

content: Boring, boring, boring. Sitting there and waiting like one of those—VCR machines? Was that it? One of those. A glorified rewind tool. It beats the paperwork you’d have to do otherwise, you guess. But wow it sucks. Headphones on, you browse through your phone, checking up on what’s happening in the wonderful land of Anywhere-But-Brockton-Bay, checking the news, scrolling through and waiting. At least there’s the benefit of being a fly on the wall for the short bursts of terse conversation that come through.
Oddly enough, Sophia seems muted, not arguing with Carlos. Aegis. Shadow Stalker. Whatever. Her voice comes through, short, succinct. “Possible mugging on 24th east.”

“On my way,” replies Carlos. Did Sophia get chewed out by her mother or something? Did Piggot crack down on her again? Your lips quirk upward as you pick up your domino mask, kicking your legs up onto the table.

“Console on standby,” you say, then yawn, stretching as you lean forward. Moments pass. You wish you could hear what was going on in more detail. Maybe you can turn the police scanner on, check for the better stuff.
“False alarm,” says Carlos.
“Acknowledged,” you say, hearing footsteps behind you. One headphone cup pops off your ear as you whip around, check, then rewind. “Hey, squirt,” you say, half-listening to the occasional chatter.
“Should’ve known,” Sophia mutters, responding to Carlos. It's picture perfect for what she would say if she was here, though.
Missy looks at you. You smile at her, rolling your eyes. “Hey,” she says, after a moment. “Just picking up some stuff.”

“Alright, see ya,” you say. There’s an urge to tell her Dean’s been looking for her, watch her face light up. You refrain, watching as she goes. Weird kid.  “Vista just came in,” you say over comms, “anything needs telling to her?”
“No,” says Carlos.
Ugh. How anticlimactic, you think. This is the worst. At least the next tourist group isn’t due for—another hour. Fantastic.
“Rewind,” Carlos says.
You immediately obey, time flipflopping backward in a spiral. “Redo,” you say into the mic, Missy’s eyes widen, and she tenses, back in front of you again.
You have to hand it to the kid, at least she knows when to shut up and get ready.

“Thanks,” says Carlos, and you smile, smug. At least there’s the small consolation of knowing how they’re relying on you. “Console, two armed hostiles, ordinaries. One potential cape. Shadow Stalker, Aegis, stepping in.”
“Acknowledged,” you say, “give ‘em hell.”

The ensuing fight takes a few minutes of awful silence. You’d like to hear what’s going on, but alas. After one of those minutes passes, Missy sits next to you. If she was any shorter, or if the chair was any higher, she might have to lean to have her feet touch the floor. She pulls on a pair of headphones, listening.
“Aegis, Shadow Stalker, do you require backup?” you ask, hoping. And although you’d just as soon toss the headset down in order to head out yourself, you’d probably just pass it up the chain instead.
“Negative,” comes the response. “We’re good.”
There’s a self-satisfied grunt from Sophia. You can hear the handcuffs tightening before her audio cuts out.

“Good,” you say, leaning back in your seat. It is a shame that you don’t know what exactly happened. Time was of the essence, after all. You sigh and turn back to browsing on your phone, your feet still on the table.
%%choice_one%%
%%choice_two%%
%%choice_save%%

choices: Chat with Missy. Might as well pass the time.
Silence is golden. Ain’t your responsibility.
Tell her to go find her shit and get going. If she isn’t going to help...
Talk with Sophia when she comes back.
Talk with Aegis when he comes back.

content: You look over at Missy. Without her costume, she looks even younger, her blonde hair cut at her shoulders. It irks you to see the adult in her facial features, and know that she’ll be naturally beautiful, in time. And probably better looking than you, with less effort. She obviously doesn’t put much into her appearance anyway, her hair looks like it was cut at Supercuts, with no product or shine to it, and there’s not a hint of makeup on her face. Maybe she’ll get a particularly bad rash of acne.
“So,” you say, looking at their outfit, “how are you doing, Missy?”
“I’m fine,” she says, quiet. Her jacket is too big for her, her shirt covered by it. She’s wearing jeans. Her shoes, scuffed, they’re slightly too big for her. “Do you know what happened?”
“No,” you say, “all they said was ‘rewind’, so I did it.”
Missy nods. “Thank you, Casey,” she says. You don’t detect any sarcasm or annoyance, so you preen slightly, leaning back a bit further in your seat.
“No problem. You going to take a shift tomorrow?”
She shrugs. “Maybe.”
Maybe. Hasn’t decided yet? Doesn’t feel like it? “You’re usually pretty eager to pick up extra shifts,” you say, plying her for answers, “something happen?”
She leaps to her feet, her face all-aglow with embarrassment and panic. “Shit. I had to go grab my stuff.”
“Say I needed you,” you volunteer. It’s a meaningless kindness. She’s already running off. You rewind.
She shrugs. “Maybe.”
“So like, do you know what happened with Dennis the other day? He break something?”
“He froze the television power cable,” she says, “I think he was annoyed with Sophia after patrol.”
“That explains it,” you say. “She was pissed. Whined about it at school. ‘If they’re going to give us the shit work, they better have this shit working,’ stuff like that. Did he hide snacks, too?”

“He asked me to put them in a box. I didn’t realize until afterward,” she says, but there’s a smile on her face. Her phone rings. She jumps up, her eyes wide, grabbing for her phone. “Shit, sorry, I completely forgot. I have to find my bag and go, nice talking to you!”
You wave goodbye, watching her talk to someone, her voice pleading.
<center>--</center>

Sophia takes off her mask, letting it fall to the side as she crashes on the couch. One arm dangles off of it, and she pulls at her utility belt, letting it, and her crossbow, fall onto the ground next to her.  “Ughhnhg,” she says, “gnghrh.”
Carlos seems just fine, although there’s some scrapes and cuts. “Thanks,” he says.

“S’my job,” you say, taking your feet off the desk, pushing away to let the wheels carry you closer to Sophia. You poke her arm. She swats at you. An easy dodge. “What happened to Shadow Princess? All tuckered out?”
Sophia makes a muffled growl, her face pushing its way out of the cushion to glare at you. “You got to sit here the entire time, bitch.”
“I worked very hard,” you say, “maybe even saved your lives. We’ll never know, since I wasn’t out there. Oh well.”
Sophia rolls her eyes, then turns back into the cushion.
“How you doing, Carlos?” you ask, giving him a wide smile. He peels off his mask, running a hand over his face.
“Just fine. Thank you,” he says, heading over to the sink to splash some water into his face. “You alright, Sophia?”
She manages a sarcastic shrug before raising a gloved hand, waving it back and forth. Shortly after, she rises, grumbling, and heads off to the showers.
“So what was that cape about?” you ask, taking your headset off and stretching. “Interesting habits? Powers?”
“Pepper spray,” Carlos says, rubbing his temples. “No powers, just a can of pepper spray and a knife. Screamed at us a lot.”
“Huh,” you say, “wonder what happened, then. What was he screaming about?”

“Called me at least four different slurs. After that, the tranq started to kick in,” Carlos says, stretching as well, one arm pulling the other into his chest. He really does have a nice physique. There go his triceps, pushing against the costume. You wonder if his powers help there, or if it’s just the workouts. Probably both.
“Nice,” you say, “is that a record?”
“No,” he says, “I’m sure there’s been worse.”
“Well, I’m going to have to ask you to keep track,” you say, “for the sake of science.”
He chuckles, a rich warm sound. “I’ll do my best. What happens if they doze off in the middle of one? Or get foamed?”
“Just mark it by the letter,” you say, smirking.
“This could be a bad idea,” Carlos says.
“Headline: Wards praised for restraint, man continues to scream creatively,” you say, framing words with your hands. Or the potential picture of Carlos.
“Thanks, Casey,” he says, standing, “I appreciate the levity. I’m going to go hit the showers myself.”

“Alright,” you say, “have fun,” you watch him go, then frown, turning back to your phone. That's late. You're late. You did have a lot of fun, though. You could totally head home now. In fact, you probably should.
%%choice_next%%
%%choice_save%%

choices: Wait for Sophia before heading home. Call Taylor while you’re waiting.
Wait for Sophia before heading home.
Leave without Sophia. Call Taylor while you’re heading home.

content: Sophia won’t take too long coming back from the showers, but… Waiting is dumb. You could be doing something. Anything. Anything except reading the magazines in the lobby. You toy with your phone, tapping at it, flipping it over in your hands. Tossing it from one to the other, letting it dangle precariously. You blink.

Now there’s an idea. Your smirk won’t leave your face as you tap in Taylor’s home phone number. The poor thing doesn’t even have a cell. Not a smartphone, not a flip phone, just a home phone. What a damn shame.
“Hebert residence,” says a man. Her father, you think.
“Hi, this is Casey, I’m a friend from school. Can I speak with Taylor, please?” you ask, smiling as you speak.
“One second,” he says. You hear a muffled call, presumably him shouting for Taylor.
“I got it, Dad,” says Taylor. Is she breathing hard?
“Oh, good,” you hear Taylor’s father say before a clicking sound.
“Hey, Taylor,” you say. “How you doing?”
“I’m—okay,” she says. Her hesitancy leads you to believe that she may not be okay.
“That’s good to hear,” you say. “I just wanted to check up with you. Did you manage to get a replacement book?”
“Yes. Thank you so much,” she says, genuine gratitude shining through. If it gets ruined, will she feel even more guilty? It’s probable. You’ll have to tell Sophia about it. “I’ll pay you-”
“You don’t have to,” you say. “It was my fault, really.”
“Thanks.”

You’ll have to spend some time figuring out where she hides next and tell—speak of the devil. You mouth Taylor to Sophia, and her eyes widen. There’s a smile on her face as she sits down across from you, pulling a jacket on. “One second,” you say. “Gotta grab my homework real fast.”
In goes the headphone jack, and you provide Sophia with an earbud. You’re such a bitch, she mouths. Or at least that’s what you think she mouths as she slips it in.

“I’m glad you’re feeling better. You should do something. Stick up to them. I’ve-” you let your voice quaver a little, Sophia silently laughing next to you, “I’ve been trying to. They’re just bullies. Do...do you think Emma’s dad would sue? If I hit her?”
Sophia’s silent laughter becomes a guffaw, and you glare at her, kicking her leg.
“I think he would,” Taylor says.
“It’s what the stuff I’ve been reading says,” you say, before mouthing bus stop to Sophia, jerking your head at the door. She nods, standing. “That if-if you fight back, it might get better?”

“I’ve tried that,” says Taylor. “You think I haven’t tried anything?” There goes all of the energy and gusto from her voice. “I wish they’d just—leave me alone. That’s all I want. Is that too much to ask?” Her voice breaks a bit. “I’m tired.”

“I’m sorry,” you say, walking with Sophia. “I shouldn’t have brought it up. I-I just...I’m tired too, you know? I don’t know how you take it. Sometimes, I think-” you allow emotion to well up in your voice. “Maybe you’d be better off if you didn’t come to school.”
Sophia has to stop for a moment, holding onto your shoulder. You think she’s crying. It’s hard to resist the urge to chuckle yourself.
Taylor doesn’t respond for a long while. “I don’t want them to win,” she says.
“I—” you begin, then punch Sophia in the arm, because she’s holding you back. The bus will be here soon. “I don’t know. What can I do? How can I help?”
‘I don’t know either. Sorry. Maybe they’ll just give up. Move on.”
Fat fucking chance, Sophia mouths. You give her a thumbs up.
“I hope so,” you say, pouring regret into your voice. “Thank you, Taylor. See you tomorrow?”
“Yeah,” Taylor says, but there’s no feeling in it. You hang up, pluck the earbud from your ear, then from Sophia’s.
“So?” you ask, a self-satisfied smile on your face.
"Pretty fucking good," she says, then nods, offering you a fist. You meet it with yours, and wait for the bus together. Tomorrow waits, with even more fun to look forward to.
%%choice_next%%
%%choice_save%%

Sophia has her physique and powers. She’ll make money, probably won’t ever be too famous, what with her dogged commitment to pissing others off, one way or another. Maybe she’ll get popular one way or another, or be a cult hero. She does tend to go overboard. Maybe she'll end up putting someone in a coma. Or maybe she’ll kill someone else who doesn't quite deserve it, and get shipped off. It’s not out of the question.

Emma has her looks. She’s pretty. Sensuous, beautiful, even. With or without makeup. Curvy. Modeling. It’s irritating that she’ll be capable of going further in that in the coming years. Who knows, maybe she’ll be an actress. Or a professional model. Whichever she is, you think she’ll be taking whatever drugs are popular. She seems to enjoy relying on crutches, using them to feel better about herself. Heroin? Cocaine? Xanax? Hydrocodone? Amphetamines? Plain old alcohol? The tabloids will eat her for lunch.

Madison, though. Madison is probably the worst of them. She has her inoffensive cuteness. Yeah, what will that do for her? She’ll go through life being nothing more than an extra. Whether that’s with other friends at Winslow, with Emma, with Sophia... Madison is someone who won’t ever make an impact, who isn’t ugly, but isn’t anything, really. The most she’ll ever be is a hanger-on to someone who means something. In the end, her life matters about as much as the people Sophia cuffed yesterday.
“Hi Madison,” you say with a smile, adjusting your bag as you keep an eye out for Taylor.

She smiles back at you, her hair restrained by barrettes, her brown hair not matching her clothing. Green top, denim jacket, grey short shorts, classic Madison discount-Disney-Channel chiq. “Hi,” she says, her voice that same chirp you remember. “How are you doing, Casey? I love your eyeliner.”
You want to check it, to make sure she’s not being sarcastic, but keep smiling instead. “Thanks,” you say, trying to find a feature you can compliment. “I like the barrettes. They’re very you.”

Her head dips down, part in appreciation, part to show them off. Two on one side. They have butterflies carved into them. Not bad. The craftsmanship isn’t awful, and they don’t look nearly as chintzy as you initially thought.
You make a murmur of appreciation before turning to your locker.
“So I was thinking,” Madison says.
After a moment, you give in. “Yes?”
“You’re friends with her, right?”
You make a noise of assent, picking up a book from your locker and sliding it into your bag.

“Well, like, either she’s just breaking down to you, or she’s just not reacting as much,” she says. You blink, thinking. Is that your fault? No, of course not. They just aren’t trying hard enough. “She doesn’t even glare. She just stares at the ground.”

“You’re just not pushing hard enough,” you say. “She’s fucked up. Ask Sophia later. I called her yesterday, let Sophia listen in. Taylor almost had a breakdown on phone. I wish I was recording.” You don’t wish you were recording. More evidence against you is bad if it ever goes wrong.
“Oh,” Madison says, looking miffed. Probably because she was left out. “Well, um, I had an idea.”
“Hm?” You ask, shutting your locker, zipping your bag up, and shouldering it. “Do tell.”
“We could plan something. Over the weekend. With everyone,” she says. “And then, on the weekday after…”
You think. Are you free this weekend? Mostly. You have some Ward stuff, but that won’t interfere. “Sure,” you say. “I’ll tell the others.”
Her face brightens. “Great! I’ll text them.”

“Cool,” you say, heading off. Taylor is late today. You wonder for a moment if she just decided not to come to school, but then you see her trudging in, spinning the dial on her locker, going through those motions. “Hey,” you say, sidling up to her. “You okay?”
“Yeah,” she says. “Thanks for asking.”
“No problem,” you say, giving her a quick hug. She flinches, then relaxes slightly. You smile, backing off, trying to keep your face suitably injured. "Sorry. I shouldn't have."
She's chewing on her lower lip, and shakes her head before giving you a slight smile. "My bad," she says.

After that little fit of awkwardness on Taylor's part, you bid her goodbye, and head on over to class. You'll be getting out early today for your Wards stuff, so you need to think of what you'll be doing then.

choices: Go do Wards stuff after school.

content: Class goes on like it always does, the teacher trying to communicate concepts to an uncaring audience. You listen, for the most part, but it’s only because the people around you are paying less attention than you. They’re talking with one another, and there’s not much that the teacher can do about it except try to be more entertaining than whatever video clip phenomena is on the rise. Whether it’s shakycam footage of a hero taking down a villain, a cape soaring by, (who knows how many videos of New Wave are posted up on a daily basis,) and nobody is talking about you. Not in the public eye for one day and you’re off the radar already.

It’s a precarious position, the life of a Ward. To be popular, to cultivate an image. You like your image. The playful trickster, ready to take advantage of weakness. A combat precog who makes a habit of humiliating enemies over the more brutal takedowns that Shadow Stalker does. It’s a good dichotomy. Yawning after a dodge always pisses someone off, no matter how cliche it is. It’s not like they can get the better of you.

The main annoyance is Clockblocker. His image niche is shared with yours. A trickster, a sarcastic character who can play havoc with time. It edges in on your established mental brand. Even worse, you’ve been paired up with him on multiple occasions. Every time it happens, the media makes it seem like you’re a pair. A thing. Look at them, walking the streets together. It’s teeth-grindingly ridiculous. He has no physique, no respect for himself, and plays the fool. Nauseating. His power is disturbing in its randomness, forcing you to rewind at inconvenient moments on occasion. You suspect he has full control over his ability, and does it to antagonize you.

The teacher asks you a question, and you answer with a beatific smile. It’s about the state of affairs in Ottawa, and the recent unveiling of a new building, current events, etcetera. It has no effect on you or anything in your future, but the teacher is happy to talk about it. And then assign homework based on it. So you sigh, pick your bag up, and head out. The teacher gives you a thumbs up and a “Good job, Casey!”
You give him a thumbs up and a smile. What a waste of time.

Thankfully it’s lunch. Time to get your food and eat. You’ll have to figure out where Taylor is hiding later, but right now you want to pry more details out of Madison. What kind of prank is it? You try to think of possibilities. Sophia probably could get her hands on a gun. Or a knife. Unmarked pills? That would fit better. Taylor’s shabby appearance, bags under her eyes, pale face… Ah, then the drug test would happen. That’s unfortunate. But Madison isn’t really privy to that set of details surrounding your cape life. So that can’t be it.
You see her first, and wait. She notices you, waves, and smiles hesitantly. You smile back, giving her a wave back.
“Hey,” she says. “How was class?”

“Awful. Nobody cared, with good reason. His favorite Canadian building. Described it down to the tiles, and how it represented a vision of..." You can't recollect exactly what he said. You'll make something up for the report. "He's got a crush on it or something, I guess. Wants to make sweet structural love. Two page essay. Won’t be a problem for the meetup, though.”
“Oh, good!” Her face is like a puppy. Happy and searching for attention.
“You should tell me about it,” you say, as you get lunch together and find somewhere to sit. “Just in case I can’t make it or something.”

“Nooo,” she says, stretching the word out as she pouts. It’s maddening. You slap her, savoring her shocked expression before letting time roll back her face into a sulky frown. “I came up with it, and want to tell everyone.”
It’s probably something lame, you think. “So, what, it’ll just wreck her stuff again?”
“Nope!” She pops the ‘p’. You tighten your grip on your fork. “I mean, that’s boring, right? Like, she doesn’t even respond anymore. If she did, I wouldn’t have to do this.”
“Right,” you say, touching your fries. They’re all so very soggy with grease, bending under your finger with no resistance. “Sure. So give me a hint, then. Please?”
“No! You gotta wait until the weekend. This is my plan.”
You cover your face with a sigh, careful not to touch your skin with those oily fingers. “Madison,” you say, muffled, “you infuriate me.”
“Aww. I’m sorry,” she says. “I promise I’ll tell you all about it soon!”
“Sure,” you say. “Whatever. Thanks.”
Maybe you can get some food at the canteen if you head out early. It can't possibly be worse than this. The only consolation is that Madison is eating it. You hope she breaks out.
<center>--</center>
“You’re kidding me,” you say. “Again?”

Missy usually takes this shift, the miniature workaholic that she is. But right now, it’s unmanned, because she’s not here. Fantastic. This would be good news, because it would mean you’re not on Console, but...

“Again,” says Dennis, his helmet off. “I’ll try not to look too amorous. I didn’t even know that a blank mask could look amorous. I’ll keep a five meter distance. Cool? If it really annoys you that much, I can call Dean…”
“I’m not upset at you,” you say to Dennis, hoping you sound conciliatory.
“Well, Missy has her own shit to deal with,” Dennis says, his voice unexpectedly grave. “So don’t get angry at her.”
“Mm,” you say, toying with your domino mask.
“So, you want to head out? Or..?”
You consider your options. Sophia has a track thing. The coach would probably give her a hard time otherwise. “Who’s on Console?”
“What’s on second.”
“What?” You blink, watching as he smirks. You grimace.
“Oh, you don’t know? I thought you knew everything. It’s a skit by-”
Time slithers back.
“What’s-” he starts.
“-on second,”you finish, rolling your eyes. “I know the skit. Who is going to be on Console, Dennis?”
“Damn,” he says, chewing his lip. “Um. I could call Dean, like I said. I feel bad because he doesn’t like saying no.”
Why is that a problem? It’s his fault.
“I’ll text Chris,” he decides, pulling out his phone and tapping away at it. “I’m sure he can make an excuse. He likes being on Console.”
“Sure,” you say.
“Unless you want to do it?”

Ugh. You’re not sure which is worse. At least after this you’ll finally get to hear about Madison’s much-vaunted prank. It’ll probably be dumping Taylor’s bags into the toilet or making fun of her dead Mother again. Maybe glue on every seat. You don’t have much confidence in her ability to creatively get to Taylor, that’s for sure.

choices: Stick it out on Console, again, and let Kid Win go out.

content: “No,” you say. “I’ll do it. Whatever. It’s fine.” Your tone makes it clear that it is fine, and to drop it.
“I mean if you don’t want to do it...” Dennis says.

You head off to do your makeup without another word. You can’t risk hitting Dennis and rewinding. Maybe he’s trying to goad you into hitting him, so he can freeze you and have them take action. So instead, you scrub at your face instead in the bathroom. Your makeup here is easier to apply, but is a more monotonous routine. Your hair tied back, you get to work.

Your fingernail traces a line around your face where the mask will go. It makes the job significantly easier, covering your eyebrows, parts of your cheekbones, and most of your nose. Useful. You apply each level of makeup slowly, methodically. Foundation and concealer go on, then you go to work, slowly matching your eyelids to the mask. You could smear it around, but no. This requires that you take care, it’s just another thing that puts you above people like Dennis, who don’t put in this effort.

A faceless helmet. That’s what makes him bush league. He doesn’t understand that when others see him, what they perceive is a faceless automaton. He may make jokes, trying his best with whatever wits he possesses, but it doesn’t match. There’s no facial expression, no smile. It’s not the face of a hero. No matter how much he might think he is.

You lift your mask, placing it against your face, the mask into place, pressing until it properly adheres itself to the skin. The rest of your time is spent contouring, making your cheekbones and jawline stand out, then—Dennis knocks on the door. Your hand jerks, and you let out a hiss of frustration, rewinding and reblending.
“Just a minute!” you call out, right before he knocks on the door.

Your lips push together in satisfaction. You don’t do lipstick, not for this. Or at least, you stopped. You’ve been too preoccupied to pick up something in an apparently less lusty tone. And you won’t ask Emma. You can see her, holding it over you, using it to depend on you, a token of reliance.

But it’s necessary to keep paying attention to how the public perceives you. Their image of you and the image you want to present should be identical, but it’s not. Unfortunate and annoying. You’ll have to work to correct that.
You walk out and smile at Dennis, who is now wearing his helmet. “Fluke,” he says, giving a little curtsy. “You look very pretty in a platonic way.”
“Thank you,” you say. “Let’s get going.”
He turns, and heads off without you. After a moment, you follow.
<center>--</center>
“Stop that.”
“Stop what?” Clockblocker asks. You hate when he takes that fake-innocent tone with you. He knows perfectly well what he’s doing.
“You’re making a tick-tock noise with your mouth.”
“Am I?” He asks. “Can you-”
Time reminds you that it wants to go forward.
You grit your teeth. Here it comes again.
clk-clok.
And again.
clk-clok.

There’s a furious scream. You want to laugh and agree with it. It shuts him up. Wonderful. Turns out it’s just a domestic argument. Some guy and lady screaming at each other on the street. You can tell Clockblocker just wants to freeze them both and leave it up to the cops. Conflict mediation doesn’t seem to be his forte. The fight quiets down. The woman pukes onto the street.
Some of it splashes onto Clockblocker’s boots. You refrain from chuckling.
“Console to Fluke, Clock, I’m getting hits on the police scanner. There’s been a report of a mugging.” Chris’ voice comes in loud and clear, and you nod to Clockblocker. “Half a block south.”
“Alright, Console,” you say, “I’m on my way. Clockblocker can wait here for-”
Clockblocker gives a strangled groan, watching as the drunk man stumbles and leans into a wall.
“Someone else to get here.” And with that, you’re off. Aah, freedom.

You keep an eye out, occasionally rewinding as you run toward the supposed mugging. Ah. This is one of those situations. The sort that Sophia would sit on her perch about, waiting for a response. You’re not really into that sort of test. Too much of a pain in the ass to watch them when you could be doing other, more useful things. If someone died on your watch, they’d probably slap you particularly hard for it, too, given your power.
Ugh.

Two gang members. Merchants seems like a reasonable assumption, given their general state of dress, and that one doesn’t seem to take issue with the other being black. “Yo, druggies,” you say. “You take credit or is it cash only?”
One brandishes a knife at you. “Get the fuck outta here,” he says.
Their victim tries to pull out of the other’s hold.

“Why? All I want is drugs. You got the good stuff? Oxy?” You step forward. “I don’t need meth, just something to take the edge off, y’know? A bit of Valium? What’s the street name for that?” Another step.
The man brandishing the knife at you swipes. You move in—
And it lodges itself in your shoulder. Damn, that hurts. Probably hit something major.
Time crawls back into its hole.

You move in, letting the knife slide by, delivering a stungun to the man’s belly. He convulses, and his hand clenches around the knife. You deliver a knee to the groin, (the knife clatters to the pavement) then zap him again. He crumples.
“Stay back, bitch, or I’ll-”
“What, you’re going to slit his throat? Upgrade from a aggravated robbery to a murder? You got a gun?”
“Yeah, I do,” he says. “So you better stay back, or I’ll-”

“You should run and ditch it. Throw it into the ocean or something. You’ve got like five minutes. Possession of a firearm probably won’t look good for you in court if you’ve already done time…” You shrug. “Well, whichever works for you.”

He hesitates. The knife is at the man’s throat. It quivers. Then he breaks and runs. Nice. Didn’t even have to rewind. “Console, this is Fluke. Situation has been resolved. There’s a guy heading east on… Wessington..?”
“Close enough,” says Chris. “I’ll call it in. Cops are two minutes.”
You hum as you secure the Merchant on the ground, cuffing him before checking on their victim. “How you doing?”

He’s not exactly fine, but he’s not bleeding out, so he’s pretty thankful. The usual. Thought he was dead, thought they were going to take everything. He’s ever so thankful, repeat, repeat. Clockblocker shows up a few minutes later. You glance at his shoes. They’re still stained. You smirk, giving him a nod.
All in a day’s work, it seems. Now it's time for the wonderful world of incident reports.

choices: Get ready for the weekend. Prepare some stuff. Maybe call Emma.
Call Sophia, tell her about what happened, then get ready for the weekend.
Make a cursory call to Taylor.

content: Paperwork goes about as well as can be expected. Yes, you saved his life, yes you didn’t get injured. Nobody died. You don’t need therapy. Yes, your statement is accurate. No, you don’t know where the other guy is hiding. It’s a circus. Some decent pictures of you, alone, by the police cruiser. And Clockblocker, alone, scraping his shoes against a wall.
Much better than the last time.
That ends up being the highlight of the patrol, mostly because there’s nothing else to do afterward. You get back to the Rig and shower, changing back into your civvies.
You mull things over. Hopefully, there won’t be too much impact or—well, they’ll probably post some trash about how the two of you have broken up. There’s no winning when they’re this dumb.
Chris is eating some instant ramen while staring at the console screen. You assume Dennis is getting snacks or whatever. “See you, Chris,” you call out.
“Mm!” he says, through a mouthful of noodles. “See you!”
You decide to call Taylor again, if only to figure out her schedule. You’ll be seeing the others over the weekend, after all.
The phone rings a few times. You wait.
“Hello, Hebert residence, Taylor speaking,” she says.
“Hey, Taylor,” you say. “It’s me, Casey.”
“Oh, hi,” she says, sounding cautious. “Are you okay?”
“I’m okay,” you say, trying not to sound too happy. “I’m heading home from the library, thought I’d give you a call. How are you doing?”
It’s a shame Sophia isn’t here. You wonder how Emma would respond. Maybe you can call Taylor when you’re over at Madison’s place. It wouldn’t be too far of a stretch.
“Oh. I’m okay,” she says.

You try not to let out an exasperated sigh. She’s not making this conversation easy. “They found me,” you say, “took some of my stuff. Dumped it into different trash cans. Threw my bag into the male bathroom.”
“...I’m sorry.” Her voice is even quieter than before. “I was…”

“It’s not your fault,” you say. There’s a certain similarity to laughter and crying, you’ve noticed. If you keep your voice on that verge of laughter, you can imitate sadness pretty well. “They called it a fucking scavenger hunt.” You let your voice break a little on the last couple words, heading toward hysterical. “I don’t know what to do.”
“It’s my fault,” she says. “You shouldn’t…”

“I guess I just wanted to tell you about that. When I was a kid, I thought all the good people got what they deserved, and the same thing happened to bad people, you know?” You laugh. ‘I just don’t know. You wouldn’t take advantage of me like that, right? They said…” Letting your voice trail off, it’s easy to let the thread dangle.
“What?” Taylor says, her voice dry, almost a croak. “What did they say?”

“Just… nevermind. I’ll talk to you later, okay? I’ve got to go. I’m sorry.” You carefully press the disconnect button and bring up Youtube, checking out whatever clips can occupy your attention. You could use your ability to waste less time, but that’s the entire point of checking these videos out, so you don’t. After what seems like hours, the bus pulls up in front of you, and you board it.
<center>--</center>

You aren’t certain what you expected to see at Madison’s house. Maybe some roses or a sparkly ribbon that doesn’t quite work with the shingles. Maybe a white picket fence with a tiny barky dog. Whatever you were expecting, this isn’t too much out of the ordinary, which fits in a different way. The house is distressingly normal. White and grey. You’ve been to Emma’s house, and poked your head in at Sophia’s.
Madison comes out the front door, trying to tug sandals onto one of her feet. Why sandals? Is she that committed to trying to make capris look good? It’s not working.
Emma follows after, a faint smile on her face. She, of course, looks just fine with her dress and jacket.
Sophia is next to you, looking bored.
“So, what’s the big plan?’ you ask. “How will Hebert quake in her very large shoes?”

“Here,” Madison says, handing you a sheet of paper as you walk. “I thought about it, and it really pissed me off. We’ve broken her stuff, taken it, sent her emails,” she keeps counting off on her fingers. “Salt in her hair, glue in her bag and seat, a drizzle of paint on both, soda splashed on her shirt…”
“Yeah,” you say, looking at the paper. It’s a very blurry picture detailing the teacher’s desk. “Stole her homework too.”
Madison laughs.
Emma smiles a quiet, slightly annoyed smile.
“Get on with it, then. What have you cooked up?” You ask, expecting very little.

“I was thinking we could get the teachers involved. Make them even less happy with her. She’s already the school loser. If she doesn’t get the hint, maybe we can show her.” Madison seems very proud of herself.
You look again at the picture. There’s circles around various objects, and then one is circled multiple times. A blurry black oblong object. “Her phone.”
Madison claps. You want to punch her for being a patronizing bitch. “Yes! I figured that we can plant it on Taylor, along with some other stolen stuff. You know, just to drive the point home.”
It’s not exactly innovative. “And then the teacher asks someone to call it, and it’s in Taylor’s bag.”
“They won’t care how it got there, just that she has it. Imagine her having to come in with her dad to explain that whole thing.”
‘What if they press charges?” you ask. “The whole thing blows wide open and gets us…”
“No way,” Sophia says, shaking her head. “The teachers are idiots. You think they notice, or care?”
“Probably not,” you mutter. “I just don’t want to get caught.”
“Well, why not…” Madison begins, her eyes wide. “Why not use your phone, Casey?”
“No,” you say. “Why would I do that?”
“You’re her friend,” Emma says. “Why not? You could accuse one of us. And then it falls apart when it’s her fault.”
%%choice_next%%
%%choice_save%%

choices: Steal and use the teacher’s phone.

content: “No,” you say. “Madison’s plan is fine. We’ll get the teacher’s phone and deliver it. There won’t be any problems.”
“You sure you’re not friends with her?” Madison says. The bitch. Is she trying to put one over you?
Your eyes narrow, and you sigh. “Well, Sophia, what happens if I slip her my phone? And then I have my work phone in my bag?”
Sophia blinks, then grimaces.
“See? It ruins the impact,” you say. “And they’ll see the second phone and wonder why Taylor didn’t take both. And if she did take both, then we’ll have problems.”
“She gets it,” says Sophia. “Just figure out whatever other shit. We going to do it to...” She looks at the picture Madison has. “Is that Sloane’s desk?’
Madison nods.

You know what teachers Taylor likes. You’ve watched her shrink into herself, her shoulders drawn in as she avoids attention, her face looking down, trying not to exist. And then there’s the teachers where that inkling of confidence comes out, that awareness that this teacher might care, or at least might not make her existence worse. “Knott,” you say. “She likes Knott. Or doesn’t hate her.”
Madison’s face crinkles into an adorable pout. You restrain yourself from kicking her in the shins. “But we aren’t in that class.”
“She’s right,” Emma says, inspecting a perfectly done nail. “What’s the point if we aren’t there?”

You search for a reason to prove your point. You shake your head. “You guys can come in, pretend you’re there for some reason. A teacher wants her. Or to ask if she’s seen her phone. She’ll look your way, convinced you’re trying something.”
Their expressions are unconvinced.
Time swirls down the drain.
“Sophia’s not in that class,” you say. “You’ll have to find an excuse to get her in there. Do you even have Sloane?”
“Yeah,” says Sophia. She looks at Madison, then at you. “I’ll figure it out.”
“Good,” you say. “I’ll get the phone into her bag. She’ll be too suspicious if it’s one of you.”
“Can you imagine?” Emma says, her lips quirking up. “‘Hi, Taylor! I just want to see your bag and totally like, not drop something in it.’”
“Actually,” you say.
“Good point,” says Sophia. “Madison, you want to distract Taylor?”
Madison’s eyes widen as she claps her hands together.
<center>--</center>

In the bathroom, you run your fingers through your hair. You pull it up, letting it fall out of place. Across your eyes, all out of order. Askew. You push it out of your face roughly, and stare at yourself. Not good enough. Nowhere near convincing enough.

You slap your cheek, hard. Little sparks blossom into pain. Your nails run over your arm, leaving thin white lines that swell into redness. You look into the mirror, your eyes downcast, a forlorn frown your only expression. You chuckle.
The door swings open. Sophia walks into the bathroom. “Wow,” she says. “You look like shit.”

“Working hard at it,” you say, giving her a grin, then looking back into the mirror. “I thought about doing a split lip too, but I don’t want my tongue running over that for the rest of the day. It’d be unpleasant.”
“Hm,” Sophia says, her fingers tracing the scratches on your wrist. “I’d just twist her arm, though. No visible damage that way.”
“Maybe you’re sending a message to her through me. Or maybe we got into an argument. Whatever. Doesn’t really matter what she thinks, just that she feels like it’s her fault.”
Sophia lets go of your hand after patting it, giving you a look. “Well, I’m going to go walk into class now.”
“Sounds good,” you say. “Try to look extra cocky.”
She punches you in the arm, then goes.
<center>--</center>
You slink into class, clutching your side, your damp backpack held slightly away from you. You find a seat away from Taylor, and put your head in your hands.
“Casey?” says the teacher. Ms. Sloane. She’s never been awful, but never been great, either. “Are you alright? You’re-” she looks at the clock. “Ten minutes late.”
“I’m fine,” you say, your voice trembling. “Just dropped my stuff. Had to clean it up.”
You hear Sophia snicker, and you have to stop yourself from smiling.

“Oh,” Ms. Sloane says, looking for an excuse not to care. She clears her throat, then turns back to the board. She finishes writing out a few more sentences. You do your best to pay attention. When the quiz comes, you’re ready.
You wait for Sophia to finish.
Madison passes by Taylor with her quiz. Taylor, predictably, pulls her bag toward herself, watching Madison come and go.
Sophia walks up to the teacher’s desk, handing her test over. Ms. Sloane is looking at one of the already-finished quizzes. “Excuse me?” she says. “I have a question.”
You get up.
You hand in the quiz with one hand. Your other hand grabs for the phone.
“Ms. Sloane! Casey-”
Time grinds back with your teeth.

It takes another three tries before you successfully palm the phone, holding it by your side, your fingernails the major contact point. Or at least as best as you can. You don’t want your fingerprints on it.
Madison raises her hand. “Ms. Sloane, can I go to the bathroom?”
She looks over at Madison, then back at the quiz papers, then nods. Madison gets up, walking by Taylor, who eyes Madison once again, her bag going underneath her seat.
Trial and error.
You kneel next to Taylor’s desk, pulling her bag out from under her.
“Hey-” she starts.
You ignore her, looking it over. There’s an unclosed zipper, but it would be extremely difficult to get the phone in there. You could try tossing it.
Time flits back.

Three tries later, and you’ve found that the phone has an amazing capacity for bursting open, spilling out into three parts. The back, the battery, and the rest of the phone. The screen only broke one in three of those tries.
Madison elbows Taylor for the fifth time.
Taylor doesn’t even look at her, just at her hands.
You lean to the side, stumbling as you walk. It takes four more before you slip the phone in without any real awareness from anyone. You’re starting to strain yourself a bit.

You sit down in your seat, trying not to let out a massive yawn. Mission accomplished. Wonderful. It’s like you’ve planted a garden. You put the seeds down, and now you’re just waiting for the realization to really sprout.
Taylor keeps to herself.
Madison returns from the bathroom.
Ms. Sloane continues to grade. She stares at a quiz. Then looks harder at it, and reaches for her phone. Her hand pats the table.
There’s that moment of realization that she’s misplaced it. The realization as she goes through her bag, her fingers searching for that familiar shape.

The moment where her search goes from measured and casual to tinged with desperation. It was right there. She didn’t forget it somewhere. It’s not under the desk. It’s not in one of the drawers. She glances behind. It’s not on the little silver shelf protruding from the whiteboard. It’s gone.
Her expression sags. Disappointment and despair. “Class,” she says. “Has anyone seen my phone?” her fingers form a square. “About this big, black?”
A murmur sweeps across the class, people shaking their heads.

Taylor is staring straight ahead. Like an animal that’s been kicked too many times, she has a sense for that windup. She doesn’t know why her body is tensing. Something bad is about to happen, so it must be related to her.
Ms. Sloane sighs. “Can anyone take their phone out of their bag to call mine? I won’t confiscate your phones. I promise.”

Taylor doesn’t touch her bag. She doesn’t have a cell phone, so why would she? This has to be about someone else, her mind tells her. Every piece of information her mind can pull up is telling her that this has nothing to do with her. She saw where Madison was. What the other girl was doing. Her bag was safe. Even if Taylor isn’t consciously aware of these facts, they all point to one thing. It can’t be her.
The clamor of people lending Ms. Sloane a phone quiets after she takes one. She begins to input her number. Each button makes a clicking sound.
You hear the call complete, the phone in Ms. Sloane’s hand ringing.
The basic ringtone coming from Taylor’s bag makes you smirk. You cover your mouth, your eyes widening. How absurd. Taylor, a thief?

The realization doesn’t hit Taylor immediately. Like the pain from getting hit, you imagine. It’s the blow that knocks the breath from you, with the blinding white agony after it. Dumb shock. She looks around herself. Then down, at her bag.
“I think it’s in Taylor’s bag!” says Madison.

You want to kick her desk. What a way to ruin that moment of realization; the moment that Taylor knows that she’s fucked, her faculties shutting down, her heart pounding in her ears as she reaches for her bag, pale face all flushed with embarrassment and shame. Her shame that this could happen to her, and shame that everyone else sees as an admission of guilt.
Taylor’s hand dips down to her bag, and she pulls it up to her desk. She reaches in. Out comes the phone. She’s trembling.
People around you are murmuring, obviously. Various statements. Wow, didn’t think she had it in her. I knew it. Had to be her. Etcetera.
She stands, walking to the front of the class, and places the phone on the desk.
“Please wait for me outside,” says Ms. Sloane. She takes the phone, puts it in her bag, and begins cleaning up her desk.
Taylor walks to the door, opens it, then closes it behind her.
Was that it?
Really?
You throw your phone at the teacher’s desk.
Time clicks back.
You hear the call complete, the phone in Ms. Sloane’s hand ringing.
You stand, manufactured shock on your face. Your phone clatters from your hand to the floor. Taylor flinches at the sound, looking at you. “No,” comes your stage-whisper. “They were right?”

Taylor looks down at her bag. It’s been ringing for a few seconds, but the dawning horror grows on her face. Then it stops. Her face is frozen, her jaw set. Taylor’s hands are trembling, but she looks resigned, picking up the bag, plucking the phone out, and getting up. She begins the walk toward-
Time shivers back.
You hear the call complete, the phone in Ms. Sloane’s hand ringing.
It’s shrill and annoying.
The upbeat ringtone cracks out another response from under Taylor’s desk.
“I knew it,” you say. “Sophia was right.”
A murmur sweeps through the class.
“Quiet,” says Ms. Sloane, promptly overriden by your classmates. “Taylor, please bring my phone to me.”
Taylor gets up, carrying the bag. Her too-wide lips set, pressing against each other, making them look thinner than they are. She walks forward.
“What’s the matter?” you ask, you jeer. “Got caught? Can’t handle it?”
Taylor stops. After a moment, she turns towards you.
“Casey, sit down,” says the faraway voice of Ms. Sloane. “Taylor. My phone.”

There’s a different sort of realization on her face, and you don’t like it. You don’t like the way her face scrunches up, in a manner bereft of any beauty, in a fashion that you know and don’t at the same time. Her mouth opens, closes, then she laughs, once, just an exhalation of disgusted breath. She’s shaking her head, turning away, walking away.
Contempt.
Disgust.
Pity.
At you.
Desks screech. It only takes a few steps. You hit her before you realize it, your fist coming up and striking her in the face. Your hand throbs. “You don’t fucking laugh at me, you-”
Someone grabs you by the shoulder.
Time creeps back.
Your hand grips the sides of her mouth. She looks at you with wide eyes.

Your heart is pounding. Big thumping beats. You don’t think you’ve ever heard it beat this loud. “You’re useless. You’ll never be anything. You’re worse off than any of them. You’ll be a fucking greeter at Walmart, scrounging for whatever funding-”
That doesn’t work. The phone rings in the background. She doesn’t understand.
Time creeps back.
“You’ve never been my friend. Pretending was so easy. You’re so desperate, wanting someone to talk to, to commiserate with. You’re so stupid to fall for it. How did you manage that?”
There’s an odd sort of acceptance along with the confusion in her eyes. No. That’s not enough. You have to win. She’s pathetic. A rat running a wheel of torment that never stops, and-
Time creeps back.

“You should have killed yourself. Just take a knife and go at it. I can show you-” No. No, this isn’t working. She doesn’t understand. You aren’t hitting home. She’s just confused, that upbeat ringtone playing in the background—you want her to hurt. You need to find those words that make her crack.
Time creeps back.
“I tried,” you say, as she walks forward. “I tried to trust you. But then this happens. I-I guess they were right.”
When she turns toward you, her eyes are shiny with tears. Her mouth opens. You need more. This isn’t enough.
Time creeps back.
“They did this to me because I defended you,” you say, gesturing at yourself, at your damp bag. “And you start stealing? They told me…”
Taylor isn’t sobbing, but there’s tears welling up, rolling down her cheeks.  She’s shaking her head, clutching her bag to herself. The ringing is muffled.
“You’re just like they said,” you say, voice soft. “You were just looking for attention.”

Her fingers tighten on the bag. Spindly fingers, nails plain, normal. Boring. Her face is ugly with emotion and panic. A thrill runs through you. You know this. You’ve won, here. You need to hammer it home. Push the point in.
“I really thought we could be friends,” you say, your voice breaking. “I don’t-I—I trusted you, Taylor. I didn’t think you’d do this.” Not good enough. Too trite. “I knew Emma had a good reason—”

“I didn’t do anything to Emma!” her voice explodes, the bag now hanging at her side. She’s glaring now. “I come back and she’s decided that she needs to treat me like crap, for what? We were friends! I didn’t do anything!”
Ms. Sloane is up, saying something ineffectual again.
Too close to anger. Almost. You almost had her.
Time creeps back.
“-really thought we could be friends,” you say, your voice breaking. “It wasn’t-I trusted you. I didn’t believe them. You were just lying to me the whole time, huh?”
“I didn’t-” she says, looking at you, her mouth half-open, her hands clinging to the bag for dear life. “I didn’t lie. I swear, I-”

“How am I supposed to believe you?” you ask. “With this?” You step forward, grabbing at the bag. Taylor lets go of it, and realizes she has nothing to hang onto. She looks even more uncomfortable, not sure where to put her hands. You reach in, pulling the phone out, pushing it into her hands. “I-” you shake your head, your face scrunching up, gazing at her for a long moment. Disgust. Contempt. Pity. All of those wonderful little emotions play across your face before you let out a short bark of sobbing laughter. You stare at the phone, then back at her face.

It’s picturesque. Gone is any sense of poise, Taylor Hebert is a wreck. She’s trembling once again, her hands clutching the phone to herself in a manner that makes her only look more guilty. Trying to hold onto it. Her nose is running. Tears stream down her face.
You turn and walk away.
<center>--</center>
<center>--</center>

You jerk forward. There’s a headache coming on. The high-pitched whine of the ringing phone in Ms. Sloane’s hand, the answering call from Taylor’s bag. There was something. Something that feels like it’s dripping through your hands, like it’s all a sieve.
Nausea comes as you hear that sound, and you massage your temples. It doesn’t help, but the pressure feels better than the throbbing pain.
You…
You won.
There’s Taylor, staring blankly at the bag now in her lap, which plays that upbeat default tune.
“Taylor,”  says Ms. Sloane. “Please bring my phone to me.”

The whispers around you speak of how she’ll probably be expelled. How she’ll get suspended for a month. How they’ve seen people stupid enough to try to steal a teacher’s phone, but this takes the cake. How Taylor Hebert is a failure. Differing opinions that converge upon a single point. She’s in trouble.
You’d be happier about it, but this splitting headache is really killing you.

choices: Down some aspirin from your bag.

content: Taylor looks stunned. She blinks, looking around, then looking at you. “I-” she says, then looks at the bag in her hands. “Huh?”
It looks so silly that if you felt like not puking you’d probably laugh. As it is-

Right, you have to pretend to be concerned. You half stand and almost topple over. Nausea swirls through your brain like it’s draining into a sinkhole, chunks of pain sloughing off into the mess that is a cogent chain of thought. “Taylor?” You half-say, half-slur, trying to shake your head.
That was a bad idea.

You fall back into your seat, feeling the cold surface of the fake-wood desk. Trying to center yourself. The world slowly steadies. Keeping your eyes closed helps, particularly with your fingers running over some idiot's idea of art scrawled into the upper right corner of the fake-wood. You open your eyes, trying to look back over at Taylor.
Taylor flinches as your eyes meet hers, her mouth half-open. “Casey?” she says.
“Taylor, please bring me my phone,” says Ms. Sloane.

“I think there’s something wrong with Casey,” Taylor says. She looks at you, then back at the front of the room, and then at her bag. It's still fucking ringing. How has that not stopped yet? You want to tear it out, throw it at Taylor, then throw it at Ms. Sloane. The cheery fucking buzz buzz buzz- “I-”
“M’fine,” you say.

Taylor takes a step toward the front of the class, then another step. She makes it there eventually. The phone makes a bzzt and a sad beep as the call is missed. Whoop de fucking doo. Taylor removes the phone from her bag after a moment of searching, then hands it to Ms. Sloane.

You, on the other hand, rummage through your bag, removing a water bottle and a selection of pills. Gritting your teeth, you rub your temples as you try to figure out a way to take them when nobody’s looking. It’s not like a cocktail of ibuprofen, aspirin, and acetaminophen is like, illegal or anything. But taking pills in front of everyone would look pretty bad. So you have to wait for a little bit until Taylor hands over the stupid phone, the teacher tells her to wait outside, and everyone watches as she leaves.

Then, the pills hit your mouth and you wash them down with water. Maybe fifteen minutes from now you’ll feel better. The bitter and sweet tastes stick around in your mouth. The throbbing headache ebbs, then grows, then ebbs again. The teacher walks out to talk with Taylor. The class starts talking. The talking gets louder. The teacher sticks her head in. The talking gets softer. The door closes, your classmates immediately resumes the loud drone that sticks into your head and swirls around.
You feel like screaming at them, but settle for pressing your palms to your temples and pushing. The nausea is almost gone, and the pain is mostly down to the levels you’ve experienced before. Ugh.

The next twenty minutes are spent massaging your temples and applying pressure to your brow. Ms. Sloane comes back in at a certain point, and there’s a burst of questions that aren’t answered. The rest of the class is a free study session, apparently.
Predictably, the pills don’t really help, but maybe they’ll work as a placebo.
Class ends, and people filter out. You get up last, once the taps and chatter stop shredding through your skull.
“Casey?” says Ms. Sloane.
“Hng?” You respond, looking at her.
“Are you okay?” she asks.
You nod, and it only makes your headache a little worse. Yay.
Sophia’s waiting at the door. Great. “Hey,” you say.
“The hell is up with you?” she asks. “Emma and Madison left to their next class. We’re going to be late.”
“Headache,” you mutter. “Used power too much, probably.”
“Probably?” she looks at you. “What’s that supposed to mean?”
“Quiet,” you say, too annoyed to keep up appearances. “Be quiet.”
Her face twists to anger, then softens. “You look like shit,” she says, mercifully quieter than before.
“Feel like it,” you say. “Did you hear what was happening to Hebert?”
“Sounded like suspension. Won’t show up for a month? She didn’t even argue.”
You laugh, then regret laughing, settling your back against a locker. Serves the bitch right. She’s getting everything she deserves. “You got a shift today?”
“Yeah,” says Sophia.

“Go kick some ass,” you say, waving her off. This is humiliating and annoying. Especially with the look of pity on her face. It reminds you of Taylor’s, and you wish you had the strength to snap at her. To tell her where she can shove that bullshit, the concern. Thinks she's better than you. She leaves, thankfully. You head down the hallway toward the next class, wondering when this will fade.
