It’s all twisted. Like strings all tangled together into one knot. And all those strings are connected to more strings. They all furl and unfurl together. Ravel and unravel? No, those mean the same thing. That’s funny, isn’t it? But the strings are all here. The knots, everywhere. No keeping track of any one thing, because the second you pull one, it all goes awry. Whether they tighten up, unspool, or fall into pieces, it’s all wrong.

How do you do this? There must be a trick to it. Maybe you pull at this, or there. To my right, left, up above. They’re all around. I’m supposed to know this, but I don’t. It’s not infuriating, like something on the tip of your tongue. There’s a way to do it, and I’m not doing it correctly. Maybe this is infuriating and I’ve forgotten it. They’re there, all around, and...
I don’t know.
I don’t know.
Going through all of this is just running my hands through sand. The wind is blowing and I can’t hold onto it. Some of it sticks to me, but-
Maybe it’s better to start over.
To let it all rest and fall apart. It’s hard to think. Hard to reason out…
What was I saying?
Knots. All sorts of knots. Grains of sand.
I miss…
I can’t remember.

It should bother me more. It doesn’t, though. The thoughts bleed away into—the water, and it washes in and out. The sand clumps together, then falls apart. It’s warm. All crinkly. Rustling against itself. Then falling back into place.
And for a second, with the grains clinging to my fingers, I can think. So I push deeper into the damp sand, trying to gather up…

It’s uncomfortable. It’s everywhere, crawling through and clawing at those nonexistent things, seating itself here and there. I know, but I don’t want it. So I let it fall, in pieces and bits, washing it all off. Trading that unpleasantness for peace.
I didn’t miss this, but I could come to.
What do you think?

It ends in forever, or all too soon. I don’t keep track. Was it worth it? I don’t know. That’s kind of the point, I guess. The world heaves around me, all those knots and sand blistering and popping, the water boiling, frothing as it retreats into itself, the tide pulling back, and back, and back. It’s all gone, leaving those knots, all those grains in stark view. I can stand there and be at the center, though I don’t know why.
It’s so pretty.
And from here I can watch the water swell up, to see it as it rushes forward, all scorching, bubbling, undulating.
All those snapped knots, those writhing pieces of thought. It’s wrong, but I don’t mind.
It’s all coming, faster, faster, a thousand thousand impacts that evaporate, burning and sizzling. It hurts, but then it’s gone and I’ve forgotten—
It’s happened again, hasn’t it? Or maybe it hasn’t. I can’t really tell, but at least it’s there. It’s all twisted. Like strings all tangled together into a knot. They all furl and unfurl...
I’m sorry. I don’t think I can help you.
I wish I could, but—
I don’t know how.
You seem nice. Do you know where to go?
Good luck!
I’ll follow later. I’m going to sit here for a moment.
14M.name: 1.M

content: Winslow. I was in front of Winslow High. I stared at it for a moment, breathing in that, brisk autumn air through my teeth, trying not to puke. Why was I here?
Then someone’s hand shoved me forward, and I stumbled. My head throbbed. I lashed out, frantic-
Sophia caught my hand. “What the fuck, Hoffman?” she said, looking at me. “The hell is up with you?”
Time lurched back, attended to by spikes of pain.
“S-sup,” I managed, turning, cursing the throbbing spikes of pain. Why had I done that? The pain was worse, now, and one of my eyes was screwed up, trying to push away the oncoming pain.
She rolled her eyes and smirked at me, her arm half-extended to strike. It dropped to her side, and I wanted to hit her. Condescending bullshit.

But there was the scent of someone’s sickly-sweet aromatic beverage in my lungs, crackly-dry leaves crushed by feet. Noise. Noise and sensations that were red-hot rebar in my brain. The cold, brisk air was my consolation prize. A fucked up, shitty one that I used. Tried to take deep sucking breaths. Put the pieces together.
“Sorry,” I said, forcing a grin. “Migraine.”
“Aww, did it take you that many tries?”
“Ha,” I said, thin, annoying, and weak. It grated, just to hear my voice. “No. Just-”
“Wow, you even sound like shit,” Sophia said, looking more concerned. “You got the flu?”
“I’m fucking fine,” I growled, immediately regretting it. “Just going to… take it easy today.”
“Whatever you say, sick girl. Flu bitch,” Sophia said, a contemptuous smirk firmly on her god damned face. I wanted to claw it off, have her feel how I felt.
“Yeah. Whatever,” I said. “Go to class.”
“Not finished,” said Sophia. “What did Piggot say?”
“Fuck her,” I groaned. “Go to class. She gave me shit for what I said. Not like I fucking killed anyone.”

Sophia looked at me, suddenly tense. Her face was frozen in her best pokerface. It wasn’t exactly a good one, but I wasn’t in a great condition to take guesses at it. Fuck. I hadn’t meant to hit that particular landmine in that way. Could I afford to rewind? “Yeah,” she said, after a long moment. “Not like you did. See you, Casey.”

“Mmn,” I said, determining that as good enough. Fuck. My locker. The dials were just as much of a pain as the people walking through the hallway. My books fell into my bag, scooped off the shelf and into the backpack without any order to it.
Emma glanced my way. I gave her a weak smile.
She returned the fake smile, turning back to her locker.
What the hell was going on? Why…
What had happened to me?

“Casey,” hissed a voice. She was wearing a lumpy sweater and jeans, as her eyes glanced right and left behind her glasses. She jumped as someone bumped into her, spinning, then turning back to you. “I-”
“Taylor,” I said, smiling. A thin, wan smile. Why now? Why did she have to show up now? “Good to see you.”
She glances for the others. They’ve vanished, of course. Good. Rewinding felt like an impossible feat. “Hey,” she said, in a murmur. She seemed cagey. Nervous.
“Good morning,” I tried next, ready to give up and head to class. “Are you alright?”
She didn’t respond, opening her locker. 48, 22, 65, came the unbidden memory. It wasn’t hard to memorize the first time, and was a lot easier than having Sophia jimmy the lock.
I slumped against the locker next to hers.
Taylor stared at her bag, looking at it for a long moment, before shaking her head and starting to head toward class. “Okay,” she said, her voice almost a murmur. “Okay.”
“Hey,” I said, then fell silent.
I knew she had heard me. She stopped for a moment, turning toward me. Her eyes looked me over, in a way that mirrored Sophia’s. “Are you… alright?”
“I’m fine,” I said, glaring at her. “Don’t-I just feel sick,” I ground out.
Taylor looked at me. She stared, looking me up and down. “I hope you feel better,” she finally said.
“Yeah,” I rolled my eyes. “Me too.”
She turned, walking off.
Fuck her.

I pulled a bottle of water from my bag, downing some of those wonderful little placebos. If this was anything like the headaches I’d had prior to this, it would fade. Slowly, but it would fade. I needed to figure out what was happening.

choices: Skip. My headache might calm down, but it can’t happen fast enough. I'll just call the others.
Emma: I did it before. Might as well try to keep things slightly predictable.
Sophia: Maybe I can figure something out.
Let's not call any of the others. I'll just embarrass myself.

content: I’ve never known what Sophia believes. Whatever she thinks, It’s not what I’d ever learned. Not from my mother, nor from my father. Nor from Emma, when she was still my friend. Why do they treat me like they do? Like they have been for—months. I walk into school and dread every moment of it. I can feel my body tense up, my breath catch as I cross that boundary into Winslow. I’m listening. Listening for Emma’s voice. For Sophia’s derisive laughter. For Madison to make a petty little insult.
Bullies are just a front. Someone who wants to make themselves feel better. They’ll go away if you fight back. If you do something. You’re not doing anything.
What am I supposed to do?

I can look to the teachers and feel like they’re just there to do their job and nothing more. If there was something in the past that I’d done to her, I—I wish Emma was my friend again, even as that thought fills my throat with bile.

How am I supposed to look, to make myself less attractive to them? An even frumpier fucking sweater? It’s easy to wash. To get the stains out when they inevitably think they’re hilarious. No matter what I do, it’s all wrong. Even if I wanted to just remove their reasons for making fun of me, for attacking me, it wouldn’t work. They’d just find new reasons, or invent them.
What could I do, to make things right?
Like Casey said, they’d just sue me if I went after Emma.
It’s not really even possible for me to act.

I miss you, Emma. Who you were, when you listened and talked. When I babbled all the time, and you didn’t mind it. When I had secrets to tell, and you kept them. I had bad days. Weeks, months of time where everything was just—

Like nothing I did was—a part of life that mattered. That my mother would never be there again. To listen to her in the living room while she graded papers, frustrated. To hear her read classics out loud. To hug her. Falling asleep on the couch as we talked about my favorite books.
And you were there. You listened, because I needed someone to listen to everything that was wrong. Because so much was wrong and I couldn’t deal with it, and it all poured out.
I trusted you.
I trusted that empathic girl because she was my sister. Someone who was capable of being there when someone was hurt.

It sounds cliche, but I’ve always been wary of Casey. I want a friend. I want someone to talk to again. I wish I could spill everything out. Tell her everything I could tell Emma. But I can’t. Casey is a different person, a different personality, who looks completely different—but I can’t.
Is that bad?

Every action I take feels like a trap. A lot of the time, I don’t want to do anything at all. Just sitting there would be easier. Not going to school, they’d win, but I wouldn’t have to feel that creeping fear as I walked toward my locker, that they’d somehow messed with it again. I’d never have that feeling when they’d tracked me down, ready to drop whatever beverage or condiment they saw fit on me. Or maybe it’d be time for Emma to bring out whatever little caustic secret she’d ferreted away, ready to pull out for this.

My mind feels off. Like there’s this sort of tension. That everything feels like it’s the same. Déjà vu, but that everything is a dream. But I guess that could just be because it’s felt like the same thing over and over for the past months. That I’m just running this hamster wheel again and again, while they try to think up new tricks.
I want to keep trying. Maybe I'll ask Casey when I see her again. Maybe I can help her.
15N.name: 1.N

content: Emma stared with distaste at the school meal. She wasn’t sure what she had been expecting, but this was not it. She poked at a fry, then poked at the ground beef patty. The fry gave under her touch, breaking into soggy white mealiness. The ground beef patty did not, resembling a substance closer to cardboard.

There was a salad and a tofu stir fry in the fridge at home, where she’d forgotten it. And her father wouldn’t come to drop it off. Stabbing at her lunch with a fork, she stared balefully at it. Her guess was that the brownie was made of the same material that the meat patty was, just with sugar on top.
A tray clattered down before her, and she looked up. Sophia, who looked rather annoyed. Her eyes focused on the tray, but she wasn’t looking at it.
“You going to sit down, or..?” Emma said, and Sophia glanced up at her.
“Uh, yeah,” Sophia finally said, dropping her bag on the table, then sitting down.

“What’s up with you?” Emma asked, taking one last glance at her tray, then at Sophia’s. Both looked the same. Brown, grey, and white. Her perfectly painted lips twitched downward. She pushed her tray away from herself. It wasn’t like she was going to eat any of it anyway.
“She’s acting off,” said Sophia, sponging a fry through soupy ketchup and staring at it with distaste. “Maybe I should call it in.”
“What is that supposed to mean,” Emma said, not really caring about the answer.
“Casey looked like shit, acted like she barely knew me, then fucking called me out for—” Sophia picked out another fry, then dropped that too, picking up her fork and knife. “Stuff.”
“Stuff,” Emma said, then stared at Sophia, waiting for elaboration.
“You know,” said Sophia, her grip tightening on her utensils as she sawed away at the patty. The patty eventually lost. “The stuff that got me my job. That they decided was a big enough problem.”
“Well, what are you waiting for, then?” Emma said, annoyed. She didn’t see what the problem was. “Call it in, get her taken in for questioning or whatever you guys do.”
“There’s a set procedure,” said Sophia. Her voice was hard, tense. She set the utensils down, looking at Emma. “And if she knows it was me, she could spill whatever she knows.”
“You still have those stashes? What the fuck, Sophia. I thought you were going to-”

“Shut up, Emma,” Sophia said. “That’s why I’m trying to think, go over it in my head again. If they take her in, they question her. It’s better to do nothing. If she’s actually gone crazy… I’m not her minder or whatever.”
Emma rolled her eyes. “You’re overthinking it. You should go help Madison out with Taylor instead of doing this. Either call it in or don’t.”
“Already done,” said Sophia. “Was way too fucking easy. She just let us take it. Didn’t run, didn’t do shit. Twisted her arm because she kept staring at us.”
“That’s it?”
“Yeah. Freaky, but whatever, she can fish her stuff out of the toilet and off the floor.” Sophia shrugged, chewing on a piece of patty. “So have you seen Casey at all?”
Emma shook her head slightly.
“Whatever,” Sophia muttered. “Probably nothing anyway.”

content: What had I done before this? Emma. I’d eaten lunch with Emma, staring across at her fucking perfect makeup, her stupid shitty hair, and my head hadn’t hurt this much.
I slid down, holding my bag, sitting in the empty hall. Fuck, it was a lot nicer when it was reasonably quiet. My headache wasn’t nearly as bad. Maybe—

But when I stood, it worsened. My head pounded, pain spreading from the bridge of my nose upward, seeping through the rest of my skull. I breathed in and out, waiting for it to settle before I made my unsteady way out of Winslow, ignoring everyone, hoping that a teacher didn’t see me. What was I supposed to do, pretend I was going to the bathroom? To the nurse’s office? If a teacher did end up spotting me, I wasn’t sure if I could rewind and still move.
I made it down the steps, put some sunglasses on, and walked out. Could have been worse. Wasn’t sure how, but it could have been.
Free, I made my way to the closest bench and sat down, my head in my hands.
This wasn’t possible.
I couldn’t—
What had happened?
Was it because of an overuse of my ability?
The edges of my memory were blurry regarding… I’d torn apart Taylor. That had been satisfying. Tugging on those heartstrings, watching her floundering attempts to deny…
Taylor. Had it been her? Not possible. I’d—no. No, someone like her didn’t get powers.

So what had it been? It was hard to think. Maybe if it was quieter, I’d be able to think. As it was, all these people. Even just those walking back and forth, some of them watching me. Some of them talking to tone another, or on their phones… Noisy. Fucks.
As I sat there, the pain ebbed again. Nothing but time did it. Taking the pills was a nice thought.

Second trigger? There were stories of it. It was like my power but on a larger scale, which made sense. Who was that hero? Narwhal? I checked my phone, squinting at the tiny letters. Forcefields that could intersect people. Fantastic. I wondered what her kill count was at.
But that was a reasonable guess.

Taylor had just been acting like the idiot she was. I’d been unable to keep up that little feed of sympathy, so she had flounced off. She was probably crying in the bathroom right now. I’d wondered off and on if she’d stop going to school altogether. Maybe if I ‘broke up’ with her publically... Maybe I could use this new power to do just that.
It could always get better, after all. I just had to figure out how to do it.
I needed to think on what took place before all… this. There was the money I gave Taylor, the patrol Sophia and Aegis went on, calling Taylor and Sophia listening in… Madison’s stupid plan.
There was nothing past Taylor’s break.
After that, it was all—the harder I tried to remember, the more it felt as if I had forgotten some irritating part of what had happened.
I’d rewound, flipflopping that minute back to where she didn’t know anything, just what she’d been accused of. She was going to get suspended?
Yeah. Suspended for a month. Who had told me that? Sophia? Emma?

I punched the bench I was sitting on; the pain from the impact felt a lot better than my head. What was the best thing I could do? I couldn’t recreate the events perfectly. They were splitting from the original way I’d manipulated them already. My abilities were limited by the threat of more pain. There wasn’t anything I cared about saving. It could burn, for all I cared about it.

I’d have to complain about my headache and how terrible it had been. Sophia wouldn’t understand, of course. Her power was to turn into a glorified wraith. She had no insight, no capacity to understand. Maybe I could tell Taylor that I’d stayed up all night, worrying about how Emma was going to pick me apart this time. That I’d skipped because of that.
I wouldn’t need to pretend to be in pain.

But then she’d pity me. That little bitch would think that I was worse than her. Condescending crocodile tears. There weren't a lot of good options. But thank goodness for small concessions, because at least I knew what Madison’s simpering, cute plan was. And my headache was easing up, little by little.

choices: Go to the Rig. Stick it out on Console. There’s no way Sophia will let me go on Patrol with what she saw of me. It’s possible I could argue, but that would involve rewinding.
Call Taylor to whine like she does, milking her for as much sympathy as I can get.

content: The sea writhes. It's a million stars, all bustling with shimmering glory. All reflected off into the distance, all circling with you.
There's nobody here except you. There's flickers of others. Momentary glimpses when those spaces between seconds are snatched up, stolen, used, borrowed, and returned.
You don't mind them. It's a heartbeat of sorts, time pulsing in and out of sync, ripples that settle.
This was the literal worst.

My peanut butter banana chocolate drizzle shake had congealed into a mess of two parts. The top part, which was a froth of banana slurry, and the bottom part, which was clumps of powdery peanut butter, murky chocolate drizzle, and milk slowly separating from water.

The cashier had been such a bitch. Hadn’t wanted to split a hundred. Said there wasn’t money in the till, I knew what she was looking at. With my sunglasses, my refusal to look at bright lights, and that I looked too young to be there with class in session.

If I’d been able to use my power, it would have been much nicer. Maybe the blender and its contents would have been thrown at her face. No, I’d probably have started with her face. Made up with blush, foundation caked on, making her face look like a misaligned desert. Perhaps then I’d move to pepper spray, watching her cry as she desperately rinsed her face, trying to get as much of it out as possible. The makeup would smear. Maybe then I would have been able to smile at her and present her with a more winsome answer. Something that would linger with her, stick in her throat for the remainder of the day. Instead, I’d just—taken out a twenty and pushed it over.

“Thank you,” she’d said, her voice filled with saccharine pride. Didn’t she know she was nothing? That her capabilities weren’t ever going to improve, that she’d be in this hopeless, piece of shit position until she died? That she’d never be anything more?
My hands took the shake, and I nursed it. Drinking the blissfully icy beverage too fast was a path to more pain. I took a seat, slipped on earbuds, plugged my phone into a charger.
And then, I waited.
Taylor didn’t have a cell phone. So, I couldn’t call Taylor until school was out. And Taylor took the bus home. So add another hour on top of that. Fuck. Boring.

I could whittle away the time, but staring at videos on YouTube and slurping down a shake? That got boring fast. The shake warmed up, and I was left with the mess. Not worth drinking, not worth even thinking about. What a load of crap that was for five bucks. How long had it been? Two hours?
Another two to go.

At least my head felt better. Vaguely. The cool air, the drink, and a constant stream of music helped as a distraction. Silence would have been better, but I wasn’t going into a library to wait out the rest of the day. And then I wouldn’t have this useless shake. Maybe I could afford a rewind. No, I wanted this pain gone. The skip back hadn’t made it any worse, just—
What had caused the skip?
The thought hurt, more from the effort of reasoning it out, so I eventually stopped, going back to watching whatever popped up to pass the time. Ugh.
<center>--</center>
I tapped Taylor’s number in. Pressed call.
The phone rang.

I waited, stalking back and forth in the street. My work phone had some texts, but I left it. I’d just say my migraine was just that bad. Easy. I’d saved a baby from falling out of a tree. A cat was about to be run over, and I had to figure out a way to stop it. Any number of possibilities that rendered my participation impossible. She had to be home by now, right?
“Hebert residence,” said Taylor. “Taylor Hebert speaking.”
I almost chirped out a faux-cheerful ‘hi’ before trying to figure out how to best approach this. “Hi, Taylor,” I eventually said. “I, um, I’m sorry for being mean to you.”
There was a pause, nothing from the other line.
“Taylor?” I asked, doing my best to make my voice to sound like it was breaking. “Are you okay?”
“I, um, hi, Casey,” she said. “I’ve—it’s been odd. I’m having a very odd day. And it’s okay. I’m sorry for bothering you.”

I blinked. “You didn’t bother me,” I said, insistent and slightly off-kilter. What was going on? “I just had such a headache in the morning, and I don’t know why. So I thought I’d be better off heading home. Especially because...”

Taylor laughed. It was an odd sound, one that left me looking around myself, checking to see if she was watching or—no, she didn’t have a cell phone. I’d called her home phone. “It’s weird. I didn’t do anything. I didn’t fight back. I let them do what they wanted, and they grabbed me, twisted my arm behind my back. Sophia called me a creepy freak.”
That definitely sounded like Sophia. “I’m sorry,” I said, imagining how exactly Sophia had done it. Probably a wrist lock. “I didn’t know.”
“You weren’t there,” Taylor said. It sounded almost—accusatory? “I—they ruined my books.”

I blinked. I’d given her money last time, to help pay for it. I’d forgotten to mention it to Sophia. A shame. “That’s terrible,” I said, putting as much pain into my voice as possible. “Can I help? Maybe give you a new book? Some money to buy it?”

Another long silence. I was irritated. This wasn’t going the way I’d imagined it. I’d wanted to see how much she’d put up with. Maybe use a rewind to stop just shy of it. It would have been worth the pain.

“I-”started Taylor. Then she fell silent again. Fuck. I wanted to just hang up on her and throw my phone into my bag. “It’s okay,” she finally said. “I think it’ll be okay. I just have to avoid them. I think I’ll just—stop taking my bag to school? Maybe just carry everything in a binder?”
“What if one of them grabs it?” I asked, wishing I could have been repeating the events of the last time I’d called Taylor. Sharing the conversation with Sophia, just to laugh at her more.
A binder? Like they wouldn’t snatch it away and shred it?
“I’ve been—thinking,” Taylor said, words slow, like she was wading through concrete with her face. “I think they’re working up to something. They aren’t satisfied. They’ll just push it.”
“Yes,” I said. “I was thinking about… fighting back. But the guide I was looking at said that it only makes it worse. They can sue. Emma’s dad is-”
“A lawyer,” Taylor said. “Yeah. Yes. I don’t know. I—” And then there was an intake of breath, a hiss through teeth, all static in my ears. “I don’t want them to win.”
It was odd to hear that in her voice.
A smidgen of determination. When I’d talked to her before, that hadn’t been there. Was it because I hadn’t been there?

The difference in tone was palpable, even though they were the same words. Were they the same words? Yes. I was fairly sure. “What should I do?” I asked, pleaded. I wanted to figure out what had caused this change. What had happened? My headache all but forgotten, I was grinning, listening with bated breath.
“I’m—not sure yet,” she said. “I’m sorry. I’ll tell you. I promise.”
“Okay,” I said, trying to make my voice sound as small as possible, and not annoyed. “I understand.”
“Goodbye,” she said, voice quiet. “Thank you, Casey.”
And then there was nothing but the sound of a phone being put back into its cradle. And my mounting irritation.
<center>--</center>

A new day, which brought with it the benefit of almost no headache. Just a lingering annoyance. And a number of text messages from—Carlos. Interesting. Sophia had been injured. Not too serious, but she wasn’t going to be going on patrol for a while, that was for sure.
Oh well.
She would have taken it as an easy cue to blame me, anyway. Maybe the enforced bedrest would calm her down.
I wasn’t that naive.

She was going to be pissy no matter what. It was my fond hope that she’d take it out on Taylor instead of trying to do so on me. Actually, it was entirely possible she would. Good. Maybe it was the fact that I'd arrived late, or the fact that Sophia was out of commission, but I didn't see Madison or Emma at their lockers. Probably moping without their favorite athlete to lighten the mood.

Oh man. I hoped that Sophia had been stabbed in the leg. An injury taking her off the track team? She'd be incensed. She'd blame me, of course, but imagining her going after Taylor while on crutches? Heh.
%%choice_next%%
%%choice_save%%

I sat down at the table and started eating. Emma would get impatient and speak. I didn’t need to look at her face to know what she was thinking, I could hear the levels of irritation. First, her fork started to hit the sides of her plastic bowl. Then there was a clack as the plastic fork met the table. I continued to eat, enjoying myself. After all, I could rewind again. No headache, no problem. Her annoyance ratcheted up, and she finally pushed it toward me, enough to come into my vision.
“Where were you yesterday?” she asked. Hissed, more like. “Sophia got stabbed.”

“Out of it,” I said, after a moment longer. I glanced up, giving her a level stare. The look on her face made me smile. It was downright pissed, her eyebrows furrowing, her face probably heated under the makeup. It wasn't a very good look for her, and it made my smile wider. “I was sick. Didn’t care enough to stick around, figured I knew enough of what was going to happen. What, am I her mom now?”
“No, but-”

“No, but,” I mimicked her, rolling my eyes. I ran a hand through my hair, pushing it out of my eyes. “Whatever, Emma. Sophia’s all about strength, right? She’ll get better. It was just a couple of thugs, one lousy stab. Why is that my responsibility now? It’s her fault, her problem.”
Her shocked face was fantastic. A real marvel that her makeup kept up with it. How much sleep had she gotten last night? It almost looked as if she had bags under them. "Casey—”
“What,” I said, my voice raising. “I’m not allowed to take one day off? Because you’re too much of a powerless, whiny diva, who thinks she’s hot stuff just because she hangs out with Wards?”
“What the-” she looked around, frantic. People were staring. Not-quite-whispering voices talked about what they'd just heard. “What are you saying-”
Time snuck back.
“Where were you yesterday?” she blathered, repeated, whatever. “Sophia got stabbed.”

“Do you know how it feels to get stabbed?” I asked her. I outlined a spot on my shoulder, then my lower abdomen. There were others, but that's what tended to happen when I got careless. “It feels really cold. It’s not the worst pain I’ve felt.” Then I sighed, rolling my eyes. “She’ll get over it. I’ll bet she whined to you about how I should have rewound. That it wasn’t her fault she got fucked up.”
Emma was glaring, but her mouth was half-open. Was that horror on her precious little face?
“Sometimes, when I’m on Console, I tell-” I laughed, shaking my head. “Nevermind. You should really get a handle on your shit before mouthing off at me.”
Time swept back.
“Where were you yesterday? Sophia got stabbed.”

“Couldn’t make it. Sick,” I said, rubbing my temples. I frowned at her, shaking my head. “I was going to throw up over the keyboard if I did anything. I’m going to go eat alone if this is what I have to deal with.” I stood, picking my tray up.
“Wait-” she said.  She was suddenly unsure. “Um. Sophia was really upset. Said it was your fault. That you were supposed to be on shift.”
How much was it possible to get away with?
“I went to go sleep off a migraine,” I said. “I didn’t want any distractions. I ignored my work phone. I’m sorry she couldn’t deal.”
“Dumb,” she said. "She was—probably pissed about stuff from earlier yesterday anyway."

My fingers tightened around the tray at the first word, but I kept my smile on for the rest of her sentence. “I didn’t know Sophia needed my help that badly with just a few itsy-bitsy thugs. Maybe she’s catching what I had.”
“Whatever,” said Emma, looking back at her food. “Sorry.”

“I’m sorry too,” I said. “Maybe she’ll be up and about tomorrow, and we can sort this all out.” I stepped away from the table, and walked to a more secluded area. I’d finish the rest of my lunch there.
Annoying.
It wasn’t my fault Sophia got injured. I poked through my plate, yawning before shoving food into my mouth and chewing it.
What was I going to do next?
I’d have to go into the Wards today. And—

I groaned. Today was when I had to patrol with Dennis. Fantastic. What kind of—Did I remember where the criminals would show up? Vaguely. Good enough. It was possible that I'd be capable of locating them far faster than he could, and take them down faster as well.
Maybe it wasn't so bad after all.
Maybe today was looking up.
%%choice_next%%
%%choice_save%%

choices: Patrol Aggressively, searching for the thugs I found last time. Since I already know what's going to happen...
Patrol Moderately, don't take any risks. I don't need to rewind too many times, my headache could come back.
Don't bother, impress them with my knowledge via the Console, kick back, and relax.

content: Sophia was the physical one. She was the one who seemed a little too comfortable giving out pain. I’d never really known too much about her, other than the fact that she was the one who was with Emma after I came back. She tripped me, then. Or tried, at least. What a petty, terrible victory to take. What else can I say?

Emma. My old best friend. She knew everything about me. I told her everything. Her eyes were always pretty, and she was nice to me. She listened when there was good and bad. I thought I knew her. I thought we’d be friends forever, pretty much. As dumb as that sounded.

Madison was popular. But she was the sort of hanger-on that Julia was, just... moreso. She was petty. Her pranks weren’t the actions that left me in physical pain, or wanting to cry like Emma’s did, but they were hurtful. Attacking my books, my bag, my clothes.
Was Emma always that way? Was I that stupid, not to notice? Would it have changed if I had changed? If I’d been better somehow? No. That was stupid. But I couldn’t stop thinking about it.

But now I was just running and hiding. More accurately, sitting outside with my lunch, eating it while listening. I’d taken the essentials and left. It was pizza, which made it easy. I chewed at it, not really noticing the taste. Cheese, sauce, crust. I was busier paying attention to the sounds of footsteps, to the voices talking in the hallways behind me.
What could I do?
Was I supposed to ask for Casey’s help? That I’d just—ended up here, not sure what was going on, what was happening, and—
I finished the pizza. Drank my water, then brushed the oily crumbs off my hands.
It was impossible. Even with people who could leap over buildings and catch bullets, it was impossible.

Casey saying words. I still couldn’t remember exactly what she’d said, but I was crying. They had hurt. Her face looked so scared, so betrayed. But it all fell apart then, into whorls and blurs. A dream. It felt like a dream that was coming true, in so many ways.

I wanted to apologize to her. But that wouldn’t make sense now. It felt odd, acting on what I ‘knew’. Did I know?  The events that played out seemed so eerily similar that I couldn’t help but believe it. But Sophia wasn’t in school today. And Casey had skipped, yesterday.

I took a bite out of the slice of pizza, chewing, then stopped. I held it in my hand, staring at it. It wasn’t easy resisting the urge to drop it, from throwing it away from myself along with the full bottle of water.

A shudder ran through me as I tried to process how much time had—gone back? This time. It had happened the previous morning, too. Some sort of reversal. I’d been walking to school off the bus—and then I was back on the bus. And it wasn’t only me. Everyone else was there, too. Nobody else noticed.

Was that it? The worst precognitive cape in the world. Capable of seeing a few days into the future, once. Seeing tens of seconds into the future at useless junctions. Or maybe I was intermittently traveling back in time for no reason, but only when I didn't care about it. Like one of those terrible jokes about people who had superpowers that did next to nothing.
Nothing else? It didn’t make sense. Or at least, this being a power was more depressing than the alternative. I finished the slice, brushed oily crumbs off my fingers, and started drinking my water.

They planted the phone in my bag, in that dream. And told Casey that I wasn’t to be trusted? That I was a thief? I wasn’t sure there, but as petty and stupid as it all had been, Ms. Sloane was going to suspend me.
I took another bite of pizza, and wanted to scream. What the fuck.

Was I just—hallucinating? I finished the slice as quickly as possible. I picked up the water bottle, opening it and drinking it. And felt like throwing up. Maybe I was a cape, just broken. Like a flickering lightbulb, wouldn’t that be great. The most incompetent cape in the history of capes. Capable of randomly traveling back in time. This was downright comical in the worst possible way. Was I supposed to tell Casey? Or my dad? What was the correct decision? “Excuse me, PRT, but I appear to be suffering from temporal difficulties. How would you best recommend I deal with this?”
They’d think it was a prank call and hang up on me. I had to figure out what was causing it. Was there a method of controlling it? Maybe there was some way to repeat it.
Maybe, maybe, maybe. The word felt like nonsense, I was going around in circles, asking myself questions again, worrying at an element I didn’t have control over.

But at the same time, oddly enough, it gave me something to—focus on? To think about, other than the bullying. I couldn’t just let it keep happening, of course. But at the same time, events were playing out differently.
Was it better to just not take any of my books? To leave my bag at home and hope they didn’t find it? This was stupid. It was all stupid. They’d figure some way to take action against me.

And as much as I wanted to figure this out, it was so tiring. Being constantly aware that they were going to do something made it worse. Not better. I already knew it, of course, but—now I knew what they might do.
18P.name: 1.P

content: A plain of windblown sand, stars, and water. There's a trick to it, but you don't know it.
You're very good at what you do, but you can't know this.
You knew that, but you came anyway, to look, to search. For what? You aren't sure.
Unfortunate.
“Hey,” says Dennis. I could see from his face that he was going to talk about Sophia too. Wonderful. “You don’t happen to know where Vista is, do you?”
I blinked, trying to parse his sentence. “Vista?” I asked. “No.”
That was right. Vista was supposed to be here. How horribly irresponsible of her. “Have you called her?”
“Yeah, like I didn’t do that first. Her phone is off.”

“That’s unusual?” I asked, rummaging through my bag for my makeup. I tried to visualize where the thugs were. If I could split off, sprint over before Dennis could, I could tell him to keep patrolling. Foisting the work onto him sounded like an excellent idea to me. I could reap the rewards, he could keep falling into obscurity, with his stupid sheets of paper and ‘random’ freezing.
“Of course it is. Missy keeps her phone on. Like, all the time. I think she prefers it to—whatever shit she’s got going on at home, y’know?”

“Right.” I kept my eyes on my bag, aware that if I looked up I wouldn’t be able to resist giving a sarcastic response. “Perfectly understandable.” Was he going to tell me about her, now? Give me her whole little spiel?
“Yeah,” Dennis said. “Anyway,” he said. “I’ll call um—”
“Chris,” I said, wanting to skip his annoying indecision and move on. “Dean makes you feel guilty.”
“You’re a real timesaver,” he muttered. “Doesn’t it take the fun out of decisions?”
“Uh huh,” I said. “It helps you make a decision faster, doesn’t it?”
“Well, what if I’m feeling contrarian, because future me chose Chris, I want to choose-”

I walked into the locker room, shutting the door behind me. Scrubbing my face, tying my hair back, it was all important. A ritual of my hard-earned expertise, sweeping it all across my face. Each layer was important, each plan and portion was separate, that came together.

It was how they saw me in costume, and it needed to be perfect. Foundation and concealer, then the eyelids. I stared at my raccoon face in the mirror and applied the finishing touches, my mask. It was important that they see my face, to see that smile and grin. To watch and speak in ways that Clockblocker couldn’t.
Dennis was stupid. Foolish to a fault. Always wanting to make jokes, always wanting to make himself feel personal to people while wearing a mask that made him so very unapproachable.
I wanted to get this over with.

Pulling the costume on was easy. Get everything all secured, figure out where to go, and get there. There had been a domestic dispute, two drunk idiots shouting at the sidewalk, with as much puke as words. I’d left Dennis to deal with it. I could do that again, or I could get him to do that in the first place, pointing out that it didn’t look like much. That I’d seen it already and it wasn’t any big deal. I could even warn him about the puke if he didn’t try to aggravate me.
Things were looking up.
<center>--</center>
I walked outside, slinging my bag beneath a table. “Ready.”
“Hey, Fluke,” said Chris, who was sitting at the console, tapping away on his tablet. He waved, then turned his attention back to his hoverboard, which was slowly rotating in midair.

I gave him a smile and waved back. All I needed to think about when doing so was when I’d walked in on him practicing on his hoverboard. He’d fallen off it and hit the sofa face-first. I had rewatched it at least six times before letting the moment pass. What a waste of space. We didn’t even need him here.
“Shall we?” asked Dennis, bowing slightly and gesturing toward the door.
I kept my smile firmly pasted on my face. “Absolutely. Let’s have some fun.”
The elevator descended, and I was picturing where everything was. Or would be, in this case. To keep track of when the little domestic would happen, and then the mugging shortly afterward.
Clk-clok went Dennis’ tongue. Everything would be a lot nicer if I had the ability to punch him. He did it in time to the doors opening, then shutting behind us. Clk-clok.
Okay, I was going to make sure Dennis got puke all over his feet. “Do you mind?” I asked.
“Hm?” he said. Like he didn’t know. Like he hadn’t done this the time before, just to get on my nerves. “What’s wrong?”

Was it possible to make sure it splattered all over his front? That rancid mix of alcohol, bile, stomach acid, and whatever else they’d eaten? “You’re making noises with your tongue.” I imitated it, putting as much disdain into the gesture as I could. Clk-clok. “I’d prefer to keep the channel clear.”
“Oh,”  Dennis said, shrugged, then kept silent. Good.
Wait. He’d done that after we were out the last time. Right?
Shit.
Dennis had fucked up somehow. Or events had changed. No, this wasn’t enough to be different. I was overthinking it.
<center>--</center>
Once we were out, I rushed ahead of him, moving into an easy jog.
“You’re in a hurry,” said Dennis, but he managed to keep up. “Did something happen?”
“Yes,” I said. “There was a scream. Didn’t you hear it?”
“No?” he said. “I didn’t hear anything.”
It was another block. I remembered the buildings. The couple had been right there, clinging to whatever vertical objects were in reach.
Except they weren’t there. Where were they? They weren’t here! Were we too early? No. That wasn’t possible. Had things changed that much? In just a fucking day?
“Well?” said Dennis. The featureless helmet looked around.
“They were—they were right there,” I said, pointing.
“I can see that,” he said, hands on his hips. “Maybe your ability just misfired.”
“My ability does not misfire,” I said, glaring at him, my hands clenched into fists.
“Sure,” he said. “Maybe they heard us coming. You okay, Fluke?”
Time wriggled back.
“No?” he said. “I didn’t hear anything.”
“My mistake,” I said. “Probably just a cat or something. Console, is there anything we could pick up on?”
“Not that I can see,” said Chris. “Nothing on scanners.”
“Quiet night, then,” said Dennis.

Fuck. No, I wasn’t letting this happen. I had a plan, and I was going to stick to it. I knew where they would be. Maybe the boozehound power couple decided not to get drunk because Shadow Stalker bled all over their apartment steps. Or maybe she’d traumatized them to the point of drinking the first time through, and hadn’t been capable this time. “Where did Stalker get stabbed?” I asked. “There’s probably some assholes around there, right?”
“Come on, Fluke,” Dennis said. “No way they’d show up there after that.”
“Then go and check it out,” I said. “No biggie, right?”
He shrugged. “Why, though?”

If I punched him fast enough, could he still freeze me? I entertained the thought, wishing I was partnered up with anyone else. Sophia. Kid Win. Even Vista would have been better. “I’m going to go check it out. I want to see where they beat the crap out of my teammate. Because she’s my friend.” Without checking if he was following, I began walking.
“You really care about Shadow Stalker that much?” he said, and I heard his footsteps behind me.
“Yes,” I said, giving him the sincerest smile I could manage. “I kind of want to see if I can give those assholes a good punch for her.”
“Amazing,” he said. I couldn’t tell if he was being sarcastic or not. “That’s cool of you.”
“Console to Fluke, Clock,” said Chris. I smiled. Finally. “ I’m getting hits on the police scanner. There’s been a report of a mugging. About half a block to your west.”
“Do you want to keep going?” he asked. “I can mop that up.”
I ground my teeth before making sure I still had a pleasant expression pasted on. “No,” I said. “I can do it. You go scout. I’ll go deal with the mugging.”
“That’s not fair to you-”

There was a scream from the—the apartments. Not in the direction of the mugging. Had it happened, just later? “Go check that out,” I said, pushing as much urgency into my voice as I could manage. “I’ll go grab the mugging.”
I could almost hear him frown with disappointment. He didn’t want to go. “You sure?”
Take the bait, I thought. “Yeah, I’ll be fine.”
“Alright. Good luck.”
“Mhm,” I said, before sprinting away.
<center>--</center>

There they were, just as scruffy as before. The same dude, who had surely gone through the same steps as before. From irritated, to alarmed, to begging. And the muggers postured and picked through his belongings. Beautiful.
“Th’fuck are you?” said one of them, holding a knife.
“Merchants, buddies, let’s all get along,” I said, flashing my widest grin. “Mugger, muggee, what’s your name? Did you want to buy the drugs?”
“N-n-” stuttered Mister Muggee.
One of the muggers brandished a gun.
I held my hands up, smirking. “What, you want to add murder to the-”
The gun went off.
A bright, burning pain flooded my abdomen, and I couldn’t catch my breath. The pain was—
Time swirled back.
“-you?”

I stepped forward. How long had it been since I’d gotten shot? A while. “Friendly Ward Fluke,” I said. “I don’t see why there’s any reason to take your gun out,” I said to mugger no. 2. “We can resolve this nice and peaceful.”
“Stay the fuck back,” said the one with the knife, holding it, pointed end out toward me.
“You know,” I said, stretching. “I really don’t like getting shot. It’s uncomfortable. What is it you’ve got in your pocket? Any priors? You shoot me, they might send you to the Birdcage, you know?”
“The fuck you on about,” said mugger no.1, looking back at his teammate, knife still held out toward me.

I took my chance then, jumping forward, one hand dipping to my belt. Out came the mugger no. 2’s pistol, but I was close enough to use the first mugger as a shield. Or a hostage, at least. My hand wrapped around his knife hand as I delivered my stungun to his stomach. He jerked, limbs twitching. But then he was falling to the floor, giving no.2 a clear line of sight with his pistol.

“Come on,” I said, goading him. I really felt like hitting him a few more times. Get some of this frustration out on him. “You’ve got a long life of meth ahead of you. No need to put those years in rehab to waste by shooting me. Just toss the gun over there, run, and I’ll conveniently forget your face.”
His hands shook.
I stepped forward.

The gun fired. The sound it made was almost concurrent with my arm feeling like it was on fire. I hissed, then took another step, keeping my smile firmly on my face. He pointed the gun upward, at my head—
Time reminded me it wanted to go forward.
“-on,” I said. I wasn’t taking that chance. “Drop the gun. You can get out of this with your ass intact. No need for murder.”
He glanced at his buddy, then at me, then dropped the gun and ran.

I picked the gun up, looking it over. I pointed it at his back, trying to aim down the sights. It took more effort than I thought it would to pull the trigger, and it jumped in my hand. “Fuck,” I said. “Missed.”
I pulled the trigger a few more times, getting a feel for it. The mugger on the ground held his head in his hands, curled up. The muggee was in a similar position.
The gun clicked empty.
“Fluke, there’s reports of gunshots-”
Time crawled back into its hole.

I picked the gun up, looking it over, then noticed the civilian staring. I gave him a smile, then presented it to him. “This yours?” I asked. This entire night had left me irritated, just a mix of frustration from things going ever so slightly askew.
He squirmed away from it. Piggot would probably give me a useless talk. Whatever. Not like I’d done anything too awful. Wish I’d hit that guy, though. I settled for cuffing the other mugger.
“Fluke, everything okay?” came Dennis’ voice. “Just a pair of drunks over here.”
“Yeah,” I said, tossing the gun off to the side, keeping an eye on the civ and mugger. “Same old, same old. Two muggers. Took one down.”
“Good job,” said Chris. “Police are en route.”

choices: Keep going. This is fuck-all in terms of victories. I don’t need the knowledge, this was fucked anyway.
Maybe I should be cautious. Stuff has changed. Sophia’s fuckup probably shifted stuff around. Stick around, give cops a statement, head home.
Call Sophia, might as well boast and offer my most sincere sympathies.
Call Emma, butter her up, get her to prod Sophia into not being so pissy.

content: I hated this. Just a couple of thugs. A duo of nothing. A victory that was supposed to happen anyway. With maybe a bit of extra puke on Dennis. The evening was still young, and there I was, wasting time when I could have been taking trash off the street.

“It’s all over my shoes,” Clockblocker said, his displeasure clear. “And I’m sure it smells awful. Win. Fluke. This is terrible. I hope you got something done. Because I’m pretty sure this is the reverse of getting things done.”
“You’re doing us a public service, Clock,” came Kid Win’s voice, after a touch of laughter. I smiled as well, waiting for any additional commentary. “If you head up 43rd, you can catch up to Fluke.”
My smile disappeared.
“Wonderful. I’ll work my way up there,” Clockblocker said.

“Anything else on the scanner?” I asked. It was possible to sprint in a random direction, looking for signs of crime, then rewind upon reaching a location. The alternative was, asking Console, then rewinding to before he’d said anything.
“Not much,” Kid Win said. “Tonight seems pretty quiet.”
I shook my head, disgusted. Useless. I started sprinting.
“Fluke, is something wrong? Console shows-”
“Heard someone scream,” I said, letting my quick breaths give my voice credence.
“Alright, sending backup-”

Didn’t matter. I tuned him out, focusing on the sound of my breath, the world around me. My feet hit the ground. I listened for any sign. Whether there was a scream, an argument, drunken belligerence, anything.
Time snapped backward.
“Fluke, is there something wrong?”

I removed my earpiece and flicked it to the side, continuing my run, taking the corner and heading down a different street. My ears strained, listening. There had to be something. The shithole this place was? There had to be.
A right. Then a left. A few civs walking down the sidewalk, who cheered and waved when they saw me. Nothing.
Time sloshed back.
I went left.

“Fluke-” Out went the earpiece. It was surprisingly hard to crush, so I just tossed it into an open dumpster. I didn’t bother running this time, just taking an easy stride. Why was I even trying? This was useless. I’d already done what I needed to. Why did I need to take risks for some stupid-ass shit?
I glanced around, growing more and more disgusted with the amount of—nothing. No crime, no screaming coming from alleyways, no gunfire. What the hell.
Damn it.
I kicked a trash can, letting out a sigh. “Fuck this shit,” I muttered. There was the sound of someone running from behind me. I spun—
“Fluke-” Clockblocker said, slowing down, panting, bent over. He was sucking in air. Out of shape, it figured. “-the hell happened? To you? You okay?”
Time slivered, slipping back.

“Tonight seems pretty quiet,” Kid Win said. He sounded happy. Probably messing with his stupid-ass hoverboard with nothing going on. I hated him just a bit more. Useless. Useless and incompetent. “Maybe we can stop early.”
“Oh, I sure do hope that isn’t a possibility,” Clockblocker said, his voice soaked in saccharine sarcasm. “I was thinking, wouldn’t it be great to let puke dry on my shoes.”
“Didn’t you wipe it off?” I asked, wanting to rub it in.
“Of course I did,” he said. “Didn’t get the chance to rinse it off yet, though, so I’m concerned about the inconvenience.”

My head twinged. It didn’t quite hurt, but it was getting there. I wanted this to be over with. I’d call Emma after, tell her I’d done it for Sophia. That it was my apology or—whatever. I’d come up with a better excuse later. “That’s good,” I muttered. Fuck. “Let’s just call it early. Not worth sitting around for…” The words didn’t come. Was I still out of it? Probably. I didn’t need to rewind to know that Clock would finish my sentence.
“Nothing and more nothing. Fluke has saved us this night. Taken out the only two criminals in Brockton Bay.” I could hear the dramatic flourish in his voice.

“Yeah, that’s me,” I said, keeping my voice as chipper as possible. I loathed him, wanting ever so badly to express it in my tone, telling him exactly what I felt about him, each word soaked in condescension.
<center>--</center>
“Have a nice night, Casey,” Dennis said as I walked toward the exit, his hair still wet from a shower.

“Mm,” I said, my phone already out. I tapped in Emma’s number. I stood at the door for a moment, waiting for—ugh. Right. Sophia wasn’t going to come. Habit. I walked out the door, hitting the call button with a yawn. It rang. Once, twice, three times before someone picked up. How was I going to approach this? Contrition seemed the best option available.
“Casey?” came Emma’s voice.
“I’m sorry,” I said immediately, inflecting hesitancy as best I could. Stuttering would have made it sound even better. “I could have been there for her.”
“What? Oh.” Emma said. Remembered indignation filled her voice, slow as molasses, dripping in with each consecutive word. “Right. Yes. Sophia.”
Was everybody stupid today, or was it just the repetition of time? “I’m really sorry,” I reiterated, trying to test the waters. “Is Sophia okay?”
“Why not call her? If you really care.” Emma asked. “I wasn’t the one who got hurt.”

I gritted my teeth, trying to think of what to say. Emma was suspicious, but that suspicion was fragile. She didn’t know the full story, if I knew Sophia. Sophia would have raged, angry and ranting. Blaming everyone else, looking to lash out. How to best use that to my advantage?
“Because I-” I said, paused, then lowered my voice, letting it choke up a little. “I was afraid.”
“Afraid of what?” Emma said. I listened for her response. How receptive was she? “That Sophia would beat the crap out of you?”

Afraid of laughing at her on crutches, maybe. “No,” I said. “I just wasn’t myself this morning, and you deserve an apology. I was still in serious pain from some sort of reaction. From my powers. I don’t have any idea when it happened.”
“So you just—passed by on your stuff yesterday because of that?” Doubt. That was doubt, which was wonderful. It meant she was thinking it over, now unsure.
“Yes,” I said. “I don’t know if I would have even been able to—to use my powers to warn her. I felt like crap, Emma. I-yeah. It wasn’t the best option, but I just couldn’t do it.”
“Oh,” said Emma.

“I just didn’t want her to be upset at me tomorrow, and if only I told her the reasons why, she wouldn’t believe me. You know Sophia, Em.” It was easy to run circles around Emma. After all, I was a hero. I was a Ward. I wasn’t on probation. And Emma? She was scared of Sophia. That little lingering fear, that if Sophia was prodded too hard, she’d react. She’d seen Sophia at her most violent. Even if Sophia couldn’t do anything to me, a prod to Emma’s self-preservation? “I don’t want her to hurt me, or anyone else. If she can’t do track for a few weeks… Or patrol?”
Emma didn’t say anything. I wanted to see her face, to see her indecision, to watch her chew those perfectly painted lips raw.
“Emma? Please,” I said, plaintive. “I didn’t mean for her to get hurt. And I was just—hoping you could talk with her. Smooth things over? A bit?”
There was an intake of breath. Then a sigh. “Fine. I’ll see what I can do. I don’t know how much she’ll listen to me, but I’ll try. You better say sorry to her too, okay?”
I rolled my eyes, my jaw clenched. Right. The entire thing wasn’t even my fault. “Yeah,” I said. “I will.”
“Good.” She hung up, and I shrugged, heading to the bus stop. I hadn’t even needed to rewind. At least that had gone flawlessly.
