%%choice_save%%

choices: Apologize to Sophia in the morning. I might as well assuage her ego after laughing at the vision of her on crutches.
Use talking with Taylor as an excuse. Maybe I can figure out what her little plan is.

content: When I read, my eyes skimmed over words, flicking back and forth. I would work my way down a page, pausing at particularly interesting portions, immersed in it all. I’d glance up at previous sentences when later portions made prior portions click. It would take a moment to realize, as my eyes skimmed over those same words, an infuriating moment of checking the page number, looking, trying to find my old spot. It was just an inconvenience, but it jolted me, left me uncomfortable, unable to get back into that same level of—involvement?
There were usually hour-long breaks between each ‘burst’ of rewinds. Except when there weren’t, and my dad asked me the same question twice, both for the first time.
“How are you doing?”

The second time, I didn’t answer for a moment—so he asked it again. And I wasn’t sure whether time had stuttered again. What was I supposed to say? Oh, I’m doing fine, dad. Between the bullying at school, the hallucinatory flip through time, and then the equivalent of a cosmic DJ spinning my life into a stumbling mess, I’m peachy. Life is fine. “I—” I hesitated again.
“School?” he asked. “It hasn’t… gotten any better? Your friend, Casey?”

My lips pressed together. I set my book down, trying to figure out a better way to phrase it. I shrugged. “Yeah,” I finally said. “It has. Gotten better, I mean. Casey has helped. She didn’t show up today. Yesterday, I mean.” I almost laughed. Was I just that detached? Days didn’t blur, that wasn’t it. The flickers, rewinds, whatever this was, it rattled me. They happened without rhyme or reason, and I couldn’t parse why. I’d searched for answers, but what existed was depressingly slim. Nothing gave me any answers. I’d tried to control it. To search for some invisible power that was somehow raging out of control. Maybe it flared up with emotions. Maybe it was when I said certain words? Maybe something else?
All a waste of time.
“That’s good,” Dad said. “She seemed nice?”

“Yeah, she—” She hadn’t offered me money to pay for the soaked book this time. Casey hadn’t been there for that. “Casey has been  pretty nice to me.” Just echoing what he’d said. I was upset about my life repeating, but here I was, just saying the same thing over again myself. “I didn’t expect her to call me. Especially after she seemed so sick?”
Describing the events of the previous day. That was a start.
“She must care for you,” he said. “I’m glad.”
“Yeah,” I said. “Yeah. I think-.” My jaw was set-
“-are you doing?” My father said, looking at me from across the hall. As I glanced up, he decided I hadn’t heard him, so he asked again. “How are you doing?”

“I’m doing fine,” I said, doing my best to keep my voice controlled, not let anything leak through. “School is okay. It’s a bit weird, you know? Stuff happens, and-it-” It was easier the third time around. Third time was the charm, right? “School isn’t as easy as I thought it would be.”
“Ain’t that the truth,” he said. “Did you need to help Emma out?”

“Yeah,” I said, after taking a deep breath, closing my eyes for a second, taking off my glasses. I rubbed the bridge of my nose, trying to figure out how to phrase it. “I’ve been hanging out with Casey more often, but she was sick yesterday. Didn’t show up. Today, she was busy.”
“Ah,” said my father, nodding. “That’s rough.”

“How’s work going?” I asked, desperate to switch the topic. The more I lied, the more I’d have to remember. And I wasn’t sure of anything, including what I’d said and what had just—vanished, poofed into an existential time hole. “Anything new?”

“Yeah,” my father said. He began to speak, lamenting about some new difficulties in budget, how more and more people were turning away from the industry, what he thought would help, the occasional headshake over hat wouldn’t.

It was nice to be quiet. To not have to keep track of everything, what existed and what didn't. When I was able to just sit there, offering the occasional moment of assent, a nod, or a question that spurred him onward, that was nice. That much, I could do that without difficulty, giving him a smile before heading off to bed.
Heh.

The very thought of Sophia on crutches. Stumping her way up the steps, all determined, her face set, her lips pressed together, fingers clenched around the handles. I’d walk up to her, laugh, then rewind and take it ‘seriously’. Easy. But that wasn’t the case.
Instead, she was coughing, sitting on the steps, a crutch next to her. “Hey,” she said, before taking a couple deep breaths, sucking in air. “Casey.”
It was a disappointing punchline. “Hey yourself,” I said, sitting next to her, keeping an eye out for the school bus Taylor came in on. “Heard you got yourself fucked up because I wasn’t there.”
“Fuck,” she said. “You.”
“Yeah,” I said, then shrugged. “I’m sorry for not going. My head was killing me. Wasn’t sure I could use my powers. Any permanent damage?”
Sophia shook her head. “Just some shit.” She breathed carefully as she spoke, taking long, slow breaths. “In my lungs and my leg. Didn’t hit an artery or anything. Was careless.”
I shrugged. “Sucks.”
She wheezed out a laugh. “Yeah, fuckin’ does. Should be good in a week. Maybe less.”
“That’s good. Missing any track stuff?”  This was getting uncomfortable.

Sophia waved a hand, shaking her head. “Probably. Didn’t check. Yet.” She was lying. Her lips folded in on themselves, a grimace. She looked at me, not quite glaring, but then shook her head and stared back at the steps.
“Alright.” We sat there for a few moments longer before she grunted, forcing herself to her feet. “Wouldn’t you be better off in a wheelchair?” I asked, watching her struggle with the crutch.
She glared at me, then had to focus on making her way up the steps. “Fuck off,” she said.
“Sorry,” I said, not sorry at all. “I’ll get you next time.” Probably. Maybe. Or maybe not. Watching her struggle with stairs was delightful.
“Better be there,” she grunted, as someone pulled the door open for her. She went through, and I turned my attention back to the steps. I sat there for a bit longer, watching the people come in.

And there was Taylor, stepping off the bus, looking harrowed, her face all pinched, glancing around herself constantly. It was a shame I couldn’t make fun of Sophia to Taylor. Or maybe I could. I chewed the thought over, stretching my arms above my head and yawning. Taylor walked down the path to Winslow, and I watched, quieting my smirk, but keeping it as a smile. “Hey,” I said, hopping off the stairs, falling in alongside her. “You alright?”
She glanced at me, blinking. Her gaze moved toward the school doors before she nodded. “Yeah,” she said, then repeated herself.
“Yeah?” I said, waiting for a more coherent response.
“Didn’t sleep too well,” she said, looking down at her hands.
“That’s a shame,” I said. “You hear about Sophia?”
She paused, looking at me, now. Her eyebrows were raised. “No. What happened?”
“She ate it, she’s on crutches now. Can’t chase you down. Or anyone.”
Taylor stopped moving for a moment, as if registering that. “Oh,” she said.
“Oh?” I asked. “Is that it? You should have seen her. Couldn’t make it up the steps without having to sit down and wheeze about it.”  We approached the doors together. Taylor shook her head.
“They’ll just take it out on me,” she said, not even looking at me, her voice soft. Damn, what a wimp. “No matter what I-”
Boring.
Time twitched back.
“Hey,” I said, hopping off the stairs—
And Taylor stumbled. Her foot had been in the air when I’d rewound. She caught herself and blinked, glancing at me before turning her gaze to her hands.
“You alright?” I asked, looking her up and down. That was odd.
It took her a second to respond. “Um. No. Not really. Didn’t-didn’t sleep too well, I guess. Haha. Still out of it.”
Was that what she’d said? I tilted my head. That was wrong. Something was wrong. “That’s a shame,” I said. I’d said that, right?
“Yeah,” she said, as if confirming it.
I started up the steps. Suddenly, I was the one struggling not to suck for air like Sophia. I tried to control my breath, but something wasn’t right.

“Weren’t you-” Taylor said, then paused. I turned, looking at her. My hands were clenched at my sides, my teeth clenched together. This was wrong. She shouldn’t have stumbled. She hadn’t stumbled before. My heart pounded. My skin itched. I glanced at the entrance to Winslow, then back to Taylor.
“What?” I asked, my voice a husky croak. I coughed, then tried again. “What?” Better. Not better. It was all worse.

“Nevermind,” Taylor said. My ears strained, listening for any suspicion. Any realization. “Just-yeah. Nevermind.” She kept going up the steps, and I let out a quiet sigh of relief. But I couldn’t let it go. I had to know. This wasn’t possible, but it was happening.
But maybe I’d fucked up. Maybe I’d acted differently, causing her to react in a manner that surprised her.
Time jittered back.
“Hey,” I said, hopping off the stairs. Falling in alongside her.

Taylor stumbled, but caught herself faster this time, watching her feet. Consternation graced her face, mixed with frustration. She seemed unaware of me in that moment, glaring at the steps before looking back up.
“You alright?” I asked.
“Yeah,” she said, false cheer and anger seeping in, sounding as if she was trying to convince herself more than me. “I’m just fine. It’s all okay. I’m good.”

“Cool,” I said. “Cool.” Suddenly, I was unsure what to do next. Taylor had some sort of power. But I didn’t know anything about it. And I couldn’t rewind to test for it. How fast could she figure it out? Could I do anything to stop her? Was it resistance to powers? A method of ignoring them? But she was unaware who was causing it. So far. Fuck. How restricted was I? How little could I accomplish? I couldn’t act and re-act while she was around.

Going our separate ways was almost a physical pleasure, now that I knew. I had to tell Sophia. Or Emma. Anyone that could help. Well, that list seemed slim. It wasn't as if I could walk up to Armsmaster and tell him about my problems.
%%choice_next%%
%%choice_save%%

choices: Tell Sophia. She should know, and hell, maybe we can just continue this way. I'll just need to be more careful about using my power around Taylor.
Tell Emma. I guess I should tell her. It'll help to win the others over, and she's the petty little boss, anyway.

content: I woke up in the bus as the brakes squealed to a halt. I jerked back, trying to check around me. For my bag, which was wrapped up in my arms. For the area around me, trying to make sure that I was at the school, and hadn’t gone back—however long. It felt as if someone was waiting behind me, ready to wrap their hands up in my hair and yank me back in time. And I couldn’t do anything about it. It was tiring, trying to keep track of it.

There were a few people staring at me. Had I drooled? Or was it just because of my reaction, wild-eyed, shoving my hair away from my face, making sure I was where I thought I was? I found I didn’t really care. We were at Winslow. And maybe it would happen and maybe it wouldn’t. I’d spent enough time staring at the computer, desperately searching for answers.
Was it just—a little thing? A tiny change in my day that I’d have to get through? A sort of temporal hiccup? What class was first? Did it matter?
“Hey,” came a voice, and I noticed Casey on the steps, looking at me. She got up, walking next to me. “You alright?”
I stared at her, blinking. I looked up at the school doors, then back to her. I nodded slowly. “Yeah,” I said. My mouth felt dry, cottony. I tried again. “Yeah.”
“Yeah?” Casey said. She raised her eyebrows, giving me a questioning look.
“Didn’t sleep too well,” I said, looking down at my hands. It was better if I didn’t spend too much time staring at one thing. That way, if I slipped back, it would be more immediately recognizable.
“That’s a shame,” Casey said. She sounded happy. “You hear about Sophia?”
I paused, turning to look at her. She stopped, and had a slight smile playing around her lips. “No. What happened?”
Casey’s smile turned into a grin. “She ate it, she’s on crutches now. Can’t chase you down. Or anyone.”

I felt sick. I knew what Sophia’s response would be. She’d just take it out on me, or delegate to Emma and Madison. Or one of the other girls. I didn’t know what she would do, but I knew it would be bad. “Oh,” I said.

“Oh?” Casey asked. “Is that it? You should have seen her. Couldn’t make it up the steps without having to sit down and wheeze about it.”  I felt even worse at that. Not that I had any sympathy for her, but more the fact that I sincerely doubted her state would result in a sudden change in heart. I didn’t want to deal with the consequences. Already, I didn’t know what was going to happen in the near future.
“They’ll just take it out on me,” I said, finally. “No matter what I-”
“Hey,” Casey said, hopping off the stairs—

I stumbled into the steps, one foot raising up when it should have been setting down. My arms shot out, as I expected to fall—but barely avoided it. Another rewind. Maybe if I'd hit my head on the steps, my powers would get the message.
“You alright?” Casey asked, her arms outstretched.
Fuck. “Um. No. Not really,” I said, giving her a smile. It felt fake. I felt fake. “Didn’t-didn’t sleep too well, I guess. Haha. Still out of it.” My words felt slow and sluggish.
“That’s a shame,” Casey said.

“Yeah,” I said. What the hell was I supposed to say? Instead of speaking, I followed Casey up the stairs. I opened my mouth, hoping to find the words before the next one came out. “Weren’t you-” I couldn’t figure out how to say it. What happened to Sophia? I heard about Sophia? Make small talk about books? I kept looking at Casey’s face and remembering the classroom, where she’d said those terrible things, where she’d blamed me. It had happened like this.
“What?” Casey asked, voice dry and papery, almost a whisper. I could barely hear her. She coughed, then tried again. “What?”
So many things didn’t add up. They just didn’t make sense. Could I tell her? Could I trust her? “Nevermind,” I said. “Just-yeah. Nevermind.” I couldn’t rely on her.
“Hey,” Casey said, hopping off the stairs.
The stairs filled my vision, and I brought my foot down, catching myself. Again. I tried not to let my annoyance show. Would it repeat a few more times? I wanted something or someone to blame.
“You alright?” Casey asked, for the third time.
“Yeah,” I said, seething. I wished I could just turn around and head home. To say ‘fuck this’ and head off. “I’m just fine. It’s all okay. I’m good.”
“Cool,” Casey said. “Cool.”
21R.name: 1.R

content: It’s hard to distinguish her shape, but she’s there again. Eyes picking apart the skyline, the parts that surround her. You are drawn like the area gravitates itself to her, like a stone dropped into a pool, wrenched inward by her presence. And it washes over her, through her, under her.
“Oh! Hi!” she’s smiling, wriggling her toes in the glimmering sand. When she speaks, her voice is a little slower, a bit more hesitant.“I was here last time. I remember that. You were here—too?”
You were.

She’s looking at the sand now, the water rolling over her knees. It ripples back, and is gone again. Her face has drawn in on itself, more pensive, more hesitant. “I don’t want-” Her voice halts, and she stares up at the sky. “I don’t want to go back,” she finally says. Her fingers worm their way into the sand, clutching at it, pulling it up, damp clumps falling through her fingers.

Her eyes refocus on the ground. She doesn’t look at you for a long while, continuing the cycle of pushing her fingers through the sand, the water rolling over her, pushing from all sides, then sliding back.
The water shines beneath her fingers, and reflects its light into the sky, meeting at the horizon.

“I-” she starts, then pauses. “Is it worth it to try? With what—with everything they’ve done? Does it even matter?” She draws into herself, pulling her legs up against her chest. “I don’t know. It’s easier just to sit. To let it all slip. I can—think. Better. This time. It’s still just easier to let it all go away.”
You wait.

She rocks back and forth. Her breathing slows. She blinks, glancing at the ground, picking at the sand. “What do you think would change? I’ve tried everything, haven’t I? I did what I was supposed to. I kept trying.” Her words sound more like a sequence of question than accusations, lilting up at the end of each sentence. “Did I do what I was supposed to? I—

“It goes away the more I cling to it. But then here makes sense. But the more here makes sense, the less I care. Wasn’t that much of that to begin with, was there?” she says, then laughs, flopping over into the sand, letting the water wash over her. She blows bubbles into the water, and it pushes her back up. She’s sitting again, looking at the sand with a quizzical expression. Her eyebrows furrow, her fingers dig, folding sand together.
The rough image of—
%%choice_image%%

—forms beneath her fingertips, not truly sculpted, instead emerging at her touch. “It’s easier,” she says. “When I don’t remember everything. There’s a point where it’s half-clear? When I can kind of feel it out but not feel anything about it?” She shrugs, frowning, staring at the sculpture. It crumbles as the water meets her abdomen, falling apart. Her fingers create another.
You wait.

“And I think—they’ve changed me. Pushed me. I wasn’t like this. Or like I was then. It’s a-” she pauses, trying to think it over, to catch those words from herself. “Grinding? Like grinding that won’t stop. Milling away at me.” Her finger pokes the sculpture in the forehead, and her frown grows deeper, more frustrated. The area spikes around her, water roiling as the stars blur. “What right did they have? Why me? Why not them? Why couldn’t she just—”
%%choice_gliii%%

Her arms shiver, and she lets out a sob, collapsing to the sand, her arms resting on her shins, clenching her wrists, tightening her grip until you can see her knuckles whiten. Her forehead pushes into her knees. The wave crashes over her, dissolving the sand once again. Her fingers swat at the water, dragging across it. It deforms for a brief moment, then reforms.  Eventually, she speaks again, words muffled by her leg. “I’m tired. I don’t want to go back. I’m sorry. It’s easier not to think.”
You wait.
“I’ll go,” she says. “I’ll just—give me a minute. Sorry.”

Winslow High. It took me a moment to get my bearings. It was simpler than the last time, but more confusing. I’d been at the door to Winslow, and now I wasn’t. None of that slight twisting moment where time righted itself. At one moment, I was up the steps. And now I wasn’t. Where was Taylor? What had happened? I had to figure it out. Who was it? Was that Taylor? Was that her power? Could she do this to me whenever she wanted? Again. It had happened a-fucking-gain.
It wasn’t fair. How was she doing it? How could I stop her? Was it because she’d realized I knew? My head didn’t hurt this time. So at least there was that.
A hand shoved me from behind. Sophia. Right. No-more-crutches-Sophia. I didn’t bother rewinding, looking for Taylor, staring past the crowd as I turned. “Hey,” I said.
“Hey,” Sophia said. She was breathing easy. Made it easier to understand her. “The hell’s up with you?”
“Nothing,” I said. “Just paranoid. Where do you think Taylor is?”
“On her bus or whatever. Why the hell would I know?” Sophia rolled her eyes.
“Yeah. I guess you wouldn’t,” I said. “Thanks anyway.” I turned away from her, and started to walk for the entrance.
“Wait,” Sophia said. I stopped, rolling my eyes.
“What?”

“Wanted to ask you about what Piggot said,” Sophia said. It took me a moment to realize what she was talking about. How long had it been since I’d talked with Piggot? Miss coronary-waiting-to-happen? What had I said? Like trying to remember what I’d had for fucking lunch a week and a half ago.
“She praised me, and I said something witty,” I said. “I’m pretty sure.”
“Right,” Sophia said, raising an eyebrow.
“Exemplary. That was the word she used.”
“Bullshit,” said Sophia. There. Now we were in the usual dialogue of talking about whatever. “She did not.”

“Yup,” I said. “That’s what she said.” I had no idea. It sounded familiar. But I couldn’t remember. I had to be careful. Taylor was likely to show up, and it wasn’t like I could rewind. Oh. Right. “Uh, by the by, we need to talk after school. Maybe lunch. Some serious shit. Not right now.”
My ears could hear the bus brake to a stop. Was that Taylor’s bus? I couldn’t remember.
“Taylor’s here,” I said. “Get going.”
“Just-”
“I can’t. Go, stop arguing,” I said, and it must have come through, because she nodded and left. Fuck.
It wasn’t Taylor’s bus. My breathing slowed. What had I been afraid of?
Time slipped back.
“-we need to talk. Taylor has powers,” I said.
Sophia laughed. Then stopped. “You’re not serious,” she said.

The bus hissed to a stop. I glanced over at it, then back to Sophia. “She knows when I rewind. She might be doing some—sort of time reversal?” I didn’t want to tell her. To admit that I didn’t know if it was Taylor. It had to be. What else could it be? That my powers weren’t under my control? That was even more laughable. Fuck. “I don’t know. I mean, I don’t know if she knows about me or not. But she’s doing something. I-”
Another bus. Fuck. I couldn’t just go over, check, and rewind.
“I get it,” said Sophia, her expression hard. “I think that’s her bus.”

Was it? Fuck, fuck, fuck. I hated this, loathed it, feeling tense and sweaty, like I couldn’t stop her. I had to watch my actions, make sure she didn’t notice or see anything. It wasn’t as bad as I thought it was. I just had to make sure she didn’t notice when I rewound.

Sophia was already going up the steps. I looked back toward the buses, trying to slow my breath, to get a smile on my face. I needed more time. But if I rewound, would she know that something was up? Would she begin to suspect? I went up the steps, going through the doors. I’d see Taylor inside.

“Taylor, hi,” I said to myself, rehearsing. My voice felt whispery. Hoarse. Not good enough. Why was I so irritated? This would be simple to deal with. This wasn’t a problem. I could control this. “Taylor, hi.” That sounded better.

Where was she? There was Emma. Sophia was talking to her. Emma looked annoyed, and glanced at me, then back to Sophia. Sophia shrugged, making a gesture I couldn’t see, then walked away from Emma. I couldn’t listen. I had to keep watch for Taylor. Why was this so damn hard? I hoped they would tell Madison as well.

There. She’d just entered, not really looking at anyone. Looking past them, really. Someone bumped into her. She flinched, stumbling to the side a bit. Her eyes looked for her locker. “Hey, Casey,” she said her voice quiet, almost lost in the noise of other people.

I shivered. Did she know now? Had something I’d done tipped her off? No. There was nothing. She spun the dial on her locker. 48, 22, 65.  “Hey, Taylor,” I said. My voice was normal, wasn’t it? It didn’t sound odd. “How are you?”
Taylor stared at the interior of her locker for a moment. What the hell was she looking for? “Fine,” she said, after what must have been ten seconds, finally turning to look at me. “I’m okay.”

“That’s good,” I said. Space cadet city over there. Her eyes never lingered on mine, instead glancing back and forth, on one object one moment, on another the next. I snapped my fingers. “Hey,” I said, a bit more harshly and annoyed than I had originally intended, and forced my tone into kind concern. “You really okay? Anything wrong at home?”

“No!” she said, blinking and meeting my eyes. It didn’t last. Back staring at a particularly interesting tile. Maybe the puke-green and shit-brown appealed to her. “I’m fine. I promise. Just—didn’t sleep well.”
“Okay. Well, if anything goes wrong, or you want to talk, I’m here, okay?”
“Yeah,” Taylor said. She wandered off, presumably to her first class. “Thank you.”
I walked away, glancing over my shoulder to make sure she wasn’t following me.

choices: Straighten out the details with Sophia. Tell her what she needs to know.
I guess I should tell Sophia everything. That Madison’s fuckup got Taylor powers somehow.
Bring it out with Emma and tell her what she needs to know.
Talk about it with everyone at lunch. Give them partial details, what they need to know, and then go to monitor Taylor. Have to make sure she’s not going to find out.

content: And how she hated those expressions of weakness. Those moments where she exposed herself. So quick to erase them. Was she afraid it would be used against her by them? After all, she derived pleasure from pushing people around. Manipulating them. Watching them make mistakes. It was something she’d never had to deal with. She did it to them, on occasion. “Redo,” she would say, with time traipsing on without so much as a stitch. She would smile at their confusion, at their paranoia and panic.

For her, sitting there and waiting was just fine. Being a fly on the wall, knowing that they were relying on her. The center of attention. But that wasn’t enough. She had to win. Pathetic. A rat running a wheel.
Casey.name: C
